adapted to accommodate over 6 or 7 but generally crowded with from 15 to 20 . the roads dry and dusty . the nights cold and frosty . ice every morning an inch or more in thickness driven at all times night and day at the furious speed of 100 miles in each 24 hours . every muscle is racked and every nerve excited . You become cold . fatigued . tired . weary . hungry and sleepy . Crowded so that it is difficult to move - roads rough rocky and dangerous - When endurance is no longer bearable you lean your head against the side of the stage or a fellow passenger and and[sic] at once you are sound asleep but the next moment the coach wheel strikes a rock and all hands are suddenly thrown headlong in a struggling mass on top of each other - In the cold damp dreary and dusty darkness of the night the amiable ladies fret and scold . their pretty babies sob and cry and the gallant men curse and swear -

  In the midst of the confusion a lady wants a Satchel or band box which was carefully packed away under the seats a day or two ago, which contains something indispensible for herself or child to have - No one knows anything about it or

at Fort Bridges. and an extremely cold morning it was.

   Passing Eastward over a Comparative level sage plain we came upon the tributaries of Green River and at 3 oclock PM we were at Bryan the present Western Terminus of the Union Pacific Rail Road
  Here we will take the Cars at 12.00 tomorrow for Omaha on the Missouri River and bid good bye to the overland stages which I think by the way actually deserve more than a mere passing notice
  But few people except those who have had actual personal experience can ever fully understand the realities of overland staging and particularly during the long cold and dusty nights of November   In our case we set out in Good spirits . cheerful gay and apparently happy with all the prospective scenes and excitements incident to overland travel . cheered by the near prospects of meeting friends and relatives on the other side of land but after a time quite a perceptible change comes over you Continuing day after day and night after night . jambed into a tightly closed and rickety stage coach not

where it is but it must be found at all hazards . and down into the mysterious depths of the Egyptian darkness among the feet, legs, hoops and skirts goes the Arms, hands, and fingers of ten or a dozen willing passengers in search of something and old boots, shoes, bonnets, satchels, valises, blankets and every other unmentionable thing is brought up from under the seats and out of the hidden recesses of the old stage coach and passed over in the direction of the lady in distress, generally to be handed back with sarcastic indignation :

  Quiet being restored and you again form yourselves together so closely that mens feet and legs become tangled up in the womens hoops, dresses and skirts so that it is not an easy matter to tell whose legs are which and thus a night wears away -
  What queer changes a night will bring about under such circumstances, what funny developments the morning reveals . every one black dirty and dusty all over . handsome bonnets, neat little hats, fancy curls

45
and big [?waterfalls?] which so beautifully ornamented the ladies heads 10 or 12 hours ago, are now scattered about promiscuously under foot and tramped down into the bottom of the dirty stage with hats, caps, petticoats, hoops and [?diapers?] : Mens clothing torn, and womens dresses ripped open, their back hair down, their eyes swollen bloodshot and inflamed, their faces dirty, their mouths and noses filled with dust, their hoops disjointed and hang scattering around, about, above, below and between their lower extremities.  their dirty babies squall, scream, yell and stink and every thing generally has a frightful tendency toward demoralization.  Yet the stage rolls on towards its destination at the same furious rate of 100 miles in every 24 hours.

  At daylight or soon after you reach a "station" generally a small rough rock, mud or log cabin of the rudest kind covered with straw or dirt, with a low door and no windows where the passengers are to have 20 minutes for breakfast and the horses are to be exchanged for "fresh" ones -
  The passengers in their cold, fatigued, weary and almost exhausted

46
days and nights we are away upon condition often worse but never better

 The road is finished to this point on its western and Course and the Construction trains run a short distance further , while thousands of men are scattered along the line of route as far as Ogden City and the grading is done a Considerable of a portion of the way = 
  Bryan is a temporary town of perhaps 500 inhabitants is built of loose boards and Canvas : and the most of the houses will be torn down and transported  to the end of the tracks again.  Board houses are cut up into squares . and are taken down at pleasure . and easily set up again .  Walls and roofs are handled in the same manner.
  Bryan is situated about ¼ mile from the East bank of Green River . on a level sandy sage plain.  The town is made up principly of rough adventurous characters :  Drunken men and women paraded the streets during the day:  Every house a gambling house or Hurdy Gurdy house &c.  No timber in this part of the Country.

condition hurry inside and crowd around a small sage brush fire. the end of the track.

  The Iron rails are something like 30 feet long and as the Car is stopped 4 men on a side simultaneously sieze [sic] hold of the rails at intervals of about 7 or 8 feet: raise them from the Car & walk forward & lay them upon the ties to the mark which has been made before then:  It scarcely touches the ties before the stake drivers 4 in number have the Iron spikes firmly driven & as the last blow of the hammer is sounded, up comes the Car again to with a few feet of the end of the rail when the breaks are shut down and and [sic] every man ready at his post the same ceremony is again repeated.
 In every branch of business enumerated and various others such as Carpenters . Masons . builders . blacksmiths . Cooks, &c &c . every man has his own duty to perform and knows his place & has his own overseer. and is in all things as well drilled as disciplined soldiers

During the day a few of us went out and witnessed the process of track laying and was able to obtain a knowledge in regard to Rail Road building which was entirely new to us:

  We ascertained that the whole force employed in the Road was about 16000. men all told - That they were divided off and assigned to the different branches of business to be performed
  The first set passed along & staked off the ground after the Engineers. then come in the Graders in swarms . with their teams, plows, picks, shovels, dirt scrapers &c & levelers.  then a set to lay the ties. then the liners . and next the track layers -
  The timber is obtained in the Mountains 20 or 30 miles away.  A certain set chops the trees, others hew the logs & others saw them off, they are then taken away by the teamsters and hauled to the road and scattered along near the route of the road
  The track levelled and the ties laid and properly lined,  a car loaded with rails is driven up to within a few few [sic] feet of

48  
dancing hall, and here from [crossed out: daylight] darkness in the evening until daylight the next morning they are required to dance for the gratification of the crowd. & for the benefit of the bar

  Any man, white or black, drunk or sober has the privilege of dancing and it is their place to dance with all and upon no pretext whatever are they expected to refuse to dance with a man, it matters not what Condition he may be in
  The Set completed the gentlemen lead their partners to the bar and each [crossed out: take] call for drinks, and the gentleman pay double the ordinary price [crossed out: for at the bar] a small percentage of which is the legitimate earnings of the ladies
  After their hasty draughts the ladies walk to the center of the room and are ready for the next set and it is seldom they are required to wait for it to be made up -
  It was really amusing to see some poor miserable drunken fellow who could scarcely stand join in the dance along side of a gay and graceful looking girl but such was the case & oftener than otherwise after

early scenes in California in the eventful days of the past 

  Gambling houses where Pharoah, Monte, and all the other favorite games were played for large sums of money, were in full blast, and crowds of hardy laborers were eagerly seeking an opportunity to venture their hard earnings upon the turn of the Card or upon some ingenius gamblers trik  where as a general rule the "more they put down the less they take up"
  Hurdy Gurdy houses are of quite a recent date in the West having been introduced about 6 or 7 years ago and where all other temptations fail they are quite apt to succeed in drawing the Cash from the pockets of the [?trenchant?] invincible adventurer of the plains
  For this enticing business a company of from 6 to a dozen young and handsome girls are obtained, are generally enlisted for a term of one two or more years, are paid a certain sum generally small, and have a certain amount of the rects
  They are then attached to a whiskey shop, with the Bar room extended into a

a quarter of a mile in length hence were delayed all day:  Day cold.  the high lands covered with snow, and considerable ice running in Green River -
Monday Nov 23 1868
All hands stayed on board the Cars for they had no other place to go. and were densely crossed with all classes of people from the accomplished ladies and gentlemen of San Francisco and the Eastern Cities. to the base born rowdy and gambler of the lowest order. in company with the [?] packet and Cut throat 

 All hands passed an uncomfortable night although fires were kept in the Cars and every effort was made to render the passengers as comfortable as possible while the rubbish was being removed from the road & a temporary track laid.
  Snow fell about an inch deep this morning, and at 9 oclock we moved up to the scene of the wreck, and at 11 oclock the workmen having worked all night had the track clear so we passed by and was soon whirling along to the Eastward over the white and deathly looking sage plain and desert along [?Cutter?] creek tributary to Green

the dance would commence, the men would only be kept from falling down by the aid of their delicate partners, and in spite of their kind efforts, it was often the case that they would stagger & fall helpless and be dragged away while some other more steady fellow would finish the dance along side of his accommodating partner
Sunday Nov 22 1868
Punctual at 12.oo the train set out and soon reached Green River station. and soon after crossing the River we recd intelligence that a train was off the track a short distance a head of us and a general smash up had occurred

  Two fright [sic] or construction trains appeared to have been passing over the road, one, but a short distance behind the other . when suddenly the axeltree of the forward train or of the Engine had broke & before the train in the rear could be stopped there was a colision [sic] and both trains were knocked into a mass of ruins, tearing up the track & obstructing it for about a

River and probably one of the most dreary and desolate looking places on the plains  We saw many Antelope today running in every direction from before the train.  And at dark we had passed over the summit of the Rocky Mts without knowing and was at Rolling Spring station a tributary of the North Platte River 

  The Summit of the Mountains is a high and Comparatively level sage plain.  Gently rolling but does not appear to be anything like a mountain summit or the Culminating point of the Continent which divides the waters of the Pacific from those of the Atlantic Ocean

Tuesday Nov 24 1868
At daylight we was at Laramie Station and soon entered the Black Hills and passed "Sherman" station the highest point on the overland road being 8234 feet above the level of the sea

  Snow banks are visible everywhere, and scattering pine timber exists in places.  We soon lost sight of the timber however & passed along over high rolling plains, without even sage brush growing upon them.  With snow about 2 inches deep arrived

[Duplicate page]

at Cheyenne a handsome town situated on an elevated plain & 519 miles west of Omaha -

  The same high rolling lands continued without a tree or a shrub when in the afternoon we found ourselves upon the extensive tracts of level lands bordering on the South Platte (north side) and gradually  approaching we soon find ourselves along side the stream or near it.  at Julesburg, and at dark we crossed the South Platte near its junction & found it to be nearly closed by ice

Wednesday Nov 25 1868
Snow an inch or two deep yet, Platte River along in plain view to the right.  Ground level. a few scattering trees along the River:  Stopped At Fremont for Breakfast.  a thriving town with heavy settlements around it and in fact sign of settlements and civilization has been visible ever since we passed Julesburg:  Day pleasant arrived at Omaha at 10 ½ oclock A.M. and found the Missouri River frozen over, except where it had been kept open by the Ferry Boat

 We left the cars on the Omaha side, and was taken

51 
We now feel as if we were at our journeys end. for at this point we all separate and each one takes a different route for his particular destination.  Clayton will take a train to some Interior City in Illinois - Cadwallader takes a southern route by the way of Cincinnati to his destination at Philadelphia.  Capron goes to a point in Ohio. and [?] [?Commad?] Foster takes the Michigan Southern route for Cold-water in Branch County while I will go on the Michigan Central R.R. to Detroit.  We visited various parts of the city, purchased tickets and prepare to bid each other good bye at an early hour tomorrow morning
Friday Nov 27 1868
Left the Michigan Central RR Depot at 8 oclock A.M. and at 7 PM was in Detroit
Saturday Nov 28 1868
Left at 8 A.M. on the Detroit & Milwaukee R.R for Grand Blanc where I arrived at 11 A.M. - This is the town in which I was raised, the scene of my early childhood, and my father my only surviving parent, now resides upon his farm 1 ½ miles N.E.

over the River
which appeared to be something less than a mile wide. in the Steam ferry Boat "Irene" and found the train in waiting on the opposite side and at about one mile was at Council Bluffs City. A pleasant looking place  situated on a high [?levee?level?] with scattering timber which gave it a handsome appearance Generally

 We were now in Iowa and our train made good progress over the gently rolling prairies all day. cold & blustering and I was pleased when night set in

Thursday Nov 26 1868
At daylight we was at "Clinton" on the Mississippi river & the train passed over on a long & high bridge.  No ice in the River.   The bridge is nearly a mile long and we cross into the State of Illinois and found no snow East of the River;  Passed Eastward over the extensive prairies for which Ill has been so long famous and at noon entered Chicago 1508 miles from Salt Lake  Fare 132 dollars in Green Backs.  Meals $1 dollar each

52
As before stated I found my father's health in failing condition.  he was afflicted by what was termed the Consumption of the Bowels, and every day appeared to grow weaker and weaker and although the best of medical aid that could be obtained was called all proved to be of no avail and at 5 minutes before 7 oclock in the evening of December the 21st 1868 he quietly breathed his last in the presence of my Brother Emory who  had arrived about an half hour previous from his home at Saginaw and our step mother and her son Charles Watkins, Clara Denstoe, Frank Jacobus, Chf Remington and myself

  My father was born at Whitestown in the State of New York in the year 1795 and on the 17th day of January, and was married to Polly Root my mother August 20 1812.  Emigrated to Michigan and settled at his farm in Grand Blanc in the year 1832 -
 His health had been poor for some months and was confined to the house when I returned, and although my presence revived him much and appeared a great relief, yet he was conscious

from the R.R. station I engaged a private conveyance and hired a man to drive me there where we arrived in a sort time & had the satisfaction of arriving in time to see my poor old father before he died, for in his old ae and affliction which was upon him it was evident he could not last long.  Yet I found him quite cheerful and able to sit up a greater portion of the time

that he must soon depart from life, for a few days previous to his death he had occasional severe Coughing spells lasting a short time but died easy and apparently without pain. his last words were "dont leave me"

  His funeral took place on the 23rd at 11 oclock at the Baptist church 1½ miles west  The funeral sermon was preached by Elder J.C. Atherton the presiding Elder

The Text was in the 39th Psalm, 7th verse "And now Lord what wait I for, my hope is in thee"

 Although the day was cold an [sic] blustering and snowy yet the funeral was largely attended, said to be the largest funeral Congregation assembled in Grand Blanc for Many Years

[newspaper clipping]
ANOTHER PIONEER SETTLER GONE.  We regret to learn that Mr. Xury Williams, one of the pioneer settler of Genesee county, died at his residence in Grand Blanc, on the 21st day of December last [inserted in ink: 1868] at the age of 74 years.  Mr. Williams removed to Michigan  from the State of New York in the spring of 1832, and settled upon a farm one and-a-half miles north-east of Grand Blanc Centre, where he resided at the time of his death.  He was well known and highly respected throughout the county, and particularly in the community in which he so long resided.   One by one the pioneer settlers of this county are departing from the scenes of their early trials and ultimate successes.

53
March 4th 1869
With the death of my father everything appears gloomy in the extreme

  The last ray of hope and last gleam of light which shone so brightly around the home of my childhood appeared to h ave suddenly vanished.

[following line marked "2" in margin]

  This no longer has the appearance of home to me.  I feel like a strange in a strange land.  I am irreconcilable to the present condition of things -

[following lines marked "21" in margin]   
The people have but little knowledge of the world - I cannot make this my home.   We miss the Six horse stages, the mule trains, the splendid  horsemenship, the jolly miners, the long tailed Chinamen, the gorgeous saloons and the gold and silver coin

   We miss the hills and mountains everywhere visible in the west  We miss the extensive forests of timber, the large trees, the [?fierce?] air, the good water, the fine trout, the abundance of game, the luscious fruit & the healthy looking men women and children

[following line marked "1" in margin}

  For the last 20 years I have looked upon this as my home but now my only home appears to be on the Pacific slope

[following line marked "3" in margin]

  After so long an absence where are our long cherised [sic] and dearly remembered friends

[following line marked "4" in margin]

  I find no one whom I know or who pretends to know me

54 
[following lines marked "16" in margin]
fully convinced of its solemn reality -

 But a few are prepared for the great change - Human Nature never  rests but is continually and rapidly advancing - It causes a man to regret his wasted life and makes him feel forlorn

[following lines marked "8" in margin]
You see boys playing in the same  roads and girls romping in the same fields where you formerly played and romped.  You know nothing about them and they care less about you.  The girls are as [?frendly?] and equally as handsome but they are strangers - If introduced to them, they look upon you with indifference and think you are old because you happened to know their parents when children.
[following lines marked "9" in margin]

 The "Old" people are all gone  No one appears to miss them.  They have passed away gradually one by one - the gray heads you now meet are those who were young when you was young

[following line marked "10" in margin]
Youth manhood and old age follow so fast that before you learn to live you are called upon to die 

  To use as mild an expression as possible, time passes away drearily.  Much more so than mining at four bits per day in the deep Canyons of the Sierra Nevadas

[following lines marked "5" in margin]
All are surprised, Yankee inquisitiveness prevails. "I never would have known you".  How you have changed" "How old you look" "Do you remember me" "Came back to get married I suppose"  "Tell us everything that has happened since you have been gone"  "Go home with me and stay a week" and a thousand other similar expressions meet you on every side -
[following lines marked "6" in margin]

 The young boys and girls, My youthful playmates where are they.  A few old men and women wrinkled with age answers "I am one" "and I", but the most of them are gone, some to other states and territories and many to the grave.  In the Cemetery you can read the history of the most of your friends [crossed out: or to say the least the most of them.]

[following lines marked "7" in margin]
Can it be possible that I have changed as much as they.  While musing upon the painful past and reflecting upon the uncertain future, In comes a bouncing woman whose family name sounds familiar and I am at once informed that she was born after my departure for the west and is now married & has several children.  If I previously had doubts as to the rapid departure of time, I am now

55
Swamps and forests - Ponds marshes & wet lands have been drained and become dry, while quite large streams have entirely dried up

 The "Rapid Rivers" appear like stagnant pools - distances are short, [crossed out: a mile appearing but a few hundred yards] Mountains are like mole hills - People Cant ride on horseback and never saw a saddle
 A Merchant or trader takes in money during the day, and deposits it in the bank at night

[following 2 lines marked "14" in margin]

 If a farmer gets a $20 Green back, he hops into his buggy and rides to the bank and takes a certificate of deposit for the same
 A small paper currency is vexing to a western man - You Cant Count it in bills of 3-5-10 & 25 cts and confusion often follows

 In making change I soon learned to gather up what was placed before me & jog along - the odd looking nickels appear more like old buttons than like money and are given away to some child friend at once
  Business men meets the farmer outside of town and buys his produce before he reaches the market.  others send out truck wagons all over the county and

[following lines marked "12" in margin]
Here are the "big woods" where 20 years ago the Ojibways built their Wigwams, hunted the deer & bear and paddled their birch Canoes and now an active man can walk all over them in five minutes and possibly may see a robbin [sic] or hear the old and familiar voice of a Black Squirrel on some large oak near by.
[following lines marked "13" in margin]

 "Large Oak" how funny it sounds yet it is the Common language of the Country - The large oaks are mere sapplings [sic] in comparison to our Common firs [cross in a circle inserted here] The forests are nothing more or less than scrubby patches of dwarf timber - the land has been cleared until but little firewood remains - A Cord of wood will buy a ton of Coal - a Coal fire shut up out of sight in an iron box is substituted for the cheerful fire place of 20 years ago
  

Great improvements have been made since I went west  Rail Roads and telegraph lines were then unknown in this part of the Country, they now run in every direction and at any time of day or night you can hear the rumbling of the Cars and the whistle of the Locomotive 

 Cities and large town have sprung up in the once impenetrable 

[cross in a circle marks text in left margin, presumably for insert in section "13"]
one Oregon tree will furnish more lumber than 40 acres of the best timbered land left in Michigan

56
[marking for "16" continues for this one line]
your way wherever you go some walking & others running as if a murder had been Committed or a City was on fire
Upon first entering Chicago I thought the whole town would be engaged in a rough & tumble fight in less than five minutes
[lines marked "17" in margin]
Go in any direction you will and every body else appears to be going the opposite way at full speed, while you appear to be the objective point and all are trying their best to run right over you

 You soon become tired of this and seek refuge and protection in the upper story of a first class hotel where a tomahawk is needed to blaze the way up in order to find the way down

[lines marked "18" in margin]

 If a person is inactive on the Streets he is run over and trampled under foot at once and no one appears to care - People endure this sort of thing as if it must necessarily be so - No one resents it
  I saw men pushed down and women & children run over but all were indifferent to the fate of others
  No one rushes to the assistance of another in distress, and no one fights for their rights thus trampled upon - You see no shooting & hear no Cursing and swearing But like a band of Buffalo the big ones run over the little ones, while they in turn are run over by the larger ones

buy every conceivable article of farm products before it is ready for sale - A farmer raises
[following lines marked "15" in margin, but unclear where designation begins]
nothing but what is easily converted into cash.  They can sell at their own doors for cash everything from an onion to a ton of hay, from a Yoke of Oxen to a sucking pig from a horse hide to a skunk skin and from a Sawlog to a whipstock - How very strange this appears to one only accustomed to see farmers make money by the sale of Cattle & sheep alone, and pay Coin for everything they buy.
[following lines marked "16" in margin]
I have been in several of the large Cities [crossed out: of the East] New York, Philadelphia, Pittsburg, Cincinnatti,[sic] Detroit & Chicago

 I was much surprised and sadly disappointed.  A western man has no knowledge of City life.  It cannot be fully realized - It never was described and never Can be -All large cities appear alike to me - You can walk all day over solid bedrock, through deep Canyons and dark gorges, among the high and overhanging cliffs of granite and basalt - You visit the [?Shipping?] and it only reminds you of a vast forest of dead timber
  Multitudes of men women and children, apparently direct from the lunatic asylum obstruct

Western people know more of human nature than any other class - they know what it is to enjoy good health and the beauties of a Cloudless sky two things seldom experienced in the East
[following two lines are marked "20" in the margin]
Eastern people are pale and sickly looking

 The older people labor but the younger are brought up in ignorance and idleness the victims of of paternal indulgence   A pure atmosphere is to them unknown -


An object a few hundred yards away appears to be several miles distant

 How different in every respect from what I expected - I am lonesome, homesick, disillusioned and shall soon return to the  mountains to the enjoyment of that agreeable freedom which none but a mountaineer can fully appreciate

[marginal line indicates that "18 continues,  for this  one line]
They have learned this from infancy and expect nothing different.  They dont know any better way to do things or that there is any other place to live 
While crossing a Crowded street in Chicago a Couple of City chaps with wide paste board colars [sic] around their necks came along in a flimsy looking wagon at full speed - The crowd stampeded before them but we were so peculiarly situated that there was danger in being run over, A Comrad Stopped short, and drew his six shooter when the driver, probably mistaking him for a Border Ruffain [sic] or an escaped Lunatic suddenly turned aside much astonished to find anyone who should object to being run over rough shod
[marginal indication of "19" for the following lines]
People of large cities know but little of actual life - The plains and Mountains is the place for the natural development of man - Twenty years of life in the west is more valuable to any one [?] three score and ten in the East  

 The pioneers of the Pacific do not rightfully appreciate their situation.  When they complain of the Condition and talk of better places, and become disheartened and speak ill of the Country or people, they know no what they do

58
Monday March 15th 1869
Since the death of my father I have felt very much like the last of the family.  It has been a sorrowful winter for me.  My old relatives & friends of 20 years ago are like strangers.  they do not appear as I had anticipated they would I see them and are introduced and very soon depart like separating from newly formed acquaintances upon any other occasion.  I cannot realize the fact that we were once friends and playmates together.  Uncles & cousins nephews and nieces the same.  in no case can I place them so as to properly realize the relationship between us:

  I have tried how to do so, but it is a failure:  Eastern Customs & Western Customs I find are widely dissimilar
  Having business East, I set out this morning passed through Detroit and on to New York, and returned through Newark, Philadelphia, Pittsburg, Columbus & Cincinatti [sic] & then to Sandusky & back by the way of Detroit again, and returned home to Grand Blanc on the 26th having travelled about 2000 miles.
  Remained at home until April 12 when I took the Cars

59
of his whereabouts.  He was at Grand Haven at the mouth of Grand River and being desirous of seeing him I set out in the morning of the 26 for that point.  Went on board the train at Grand Blanc at 9.05 AM. and was at the Holly junction at 9:40 where I was obliged to wait until 12 25 for the Grand River train at which time I set out and was at Grand Haven at 7 30 P.M distance 150 from Grand Blanc
Thursday May 27 1869
I found my Brother at an early hour this morning and remained during the day, and set out on my return at 6 P.M. and was at Holly at day light next morning & soon after was at Grand Blanc

 Went to Flint the County Seat of Genesee County 8 miles from the place of my youthful residence & home, purchased ticket for Salt Lake of W. O. Donohue General ticket agent $120 -15 L.T.

Monday May 31 1869
I set out on my return to Oregon overland:  The parting with my many newly made acquaintances & friends was painful indeed

  Left Grand Blanc at 9.05 A.M. and at 12 15 was in Detroit a distance of 60 miles

again for Detroit and arrived there at noon and at 3½ PM went on board the Steamer Reindeer and at 5 P.M. landed at the wharf of my old friend William Ives on Gross Isle where he has a fine farm and is comfortably situated

  I am deeply indebted to Mr Ives for numerous [?favors?].  I went out to Oregon with him in 1851, and after I was wounded by the Indians he Contributed liberally for my benefit
  Remained a couple of days & again returned to Grand Blanc
  Frequently visited Brother Emory & family at Saginaw & also other points in the State, formed a large number of new acquaintances and among those to be ever prized is Hattie Williams my niece, daughter of my oldest brother D. S. Williams
  Hattie was about a year old when I went west, and as cross as a child ever was, and now in the little cross patch I found an amiable and accomplished lady of 19
  On the 25th May 1869 I recd a letter from my oldest Brother Daniel & learned for the first time since my return

Tuesday June 1 1869
We left Detroit last evening at 5 30 on the Michigan Southern & Northern Indiana Rail Road and at 6 30 this morning was at Chicago 284 miles and was conveyed by the Omnibus line to the Depot of the Chicago & North Western R.R. and at 8 15 A.M. set out on the Western bound train, passed through Illinois over the wide and beautifully rolling praries [sic] generally under a high state of Cultivation with occasional small groves of timber, beautiful green grass, surface crimson with flowers, corn fields striped with their green rows.

  At 3 40 P.M. crossed over the fine R.R. Bridge to Clinton where we are obliged to remain until the arrival of the regular Omaha train

Wednesday June 2 1869
At 9 25 last night we again set out to the westward and at daylight was at Marshall 151 miles from Clinton

  Praries green and handsome gently rolling, scattering farm houses, with farms under a good state of Cultivation no timber except along and near the streams, where may be noticed handsome groves

60
of oak, elm and other small shrubbery peculiar to a prarie country.

   The praries today are much more rolling and diversified than yesterday in Illinois:  RR stations appear at the usual intervals along the road some of which have become quite brisk little towns - A few prarie chickens and now and then a duck was seen along the route in the Marshes
   We reached the Missouri River at 4 PM. and was met by the Omnibus line about ¼ mile from the River and was driven on board the Steam ferry Boat "Geiser" & was soon landed at Omaha in Nebraska whre we again went on board the train & set out at 5 15 P.M. and after a distance of 3 miles the Engine became nearly unserviceable by some part of the machinery giving way another train was backed back to Omaha where a new Engine was obtained an [sic]  in half an hour set out & at sundown was at Fremont  46 miles

Thursday June 3 1869
At day light this morning was at Plumb Creek where a few soldiers & diggers were to be seen, the Platte River a short distance to our left, no timber in sight except a few trees along the River

[Postcard with picture of two mounted Indians armed with spears.]
[Text under the picture reads:]
H. B. Mollhousen                    T. Sinclair's [?lith.?] Phil d

To the Northward in the long dim distance the land raises and appears more rolling while to the Southward of the River a few miles a low range of hills appear to rise and obscure the horizon with no timber or shrubbery of any kind visible

  The ground along this levl [sic] plain appears to be alkalied & the soil not the best, and the grass inclined to be dwarfish, and although the surface is handsome yet for general beauty does not Compare with Illinois, Iowa or Eastern Nebraska - Saw a few rabbits and several Antelope [crossed out:  today] this morning:  At 8 oclock AM we crossed         [?North?] Platte which is nearly a half mile wide and stopped for Breakfast at the North Platte station a few yards beyond
  At each station aside from the Company buildings appear to be a few business houses generally of a temporary appearance - and nearly every house is a store hotel and whiskey shop combined
  But little building timber is to be found in the Country and buildings are often built of brush, adobes and dirt
  The Road continues up and

61
along the North side of the South Platte through the same kind of open grassy Country. the hilly land on the North gradually approaching the River, while the hills on the south appear to sink away in the dim distance bounding the horizon by a clear and undulating prarie as far as the Eye can reach   

   The day was bright and warm, passed more troops  At the various stations around which were generally encamped little crowds of dirty, greasy digger Indians
    At 11 A.M. was at Julesburg situated on the level plain about a mile from the River
    Old Fort Sedgewick looming up over on the South side of the River now principly [sic] [crossed out: lef] abandoned
    The [sic] gradually leaving the River and at noon was at "Lodge Pole" situated on Lodge Pole Creek a tributary of the Platte, and in this vicinity much Indian depredation was committed last year, and troops are now stationed in different parts along the line of road and vicinity
  Took dinner at "Sidney" a rest station where the Company have erected large and extensive brick buildings -
   From Julesburg the ground is alive with prarie dogs, and prickly pear abounds.  We are now entering the hilly country, poor grass, no timber

[Duplicate page]
To the Northward in the long dim distance the land raises and appears more rolling while to the Southward of the River a few miles a low range of hills appear to rise and obscure the horizon with no timber or shrubbery of any kind visible

  The ground along this levl [sic] plain appears to be alkalied & the soil not the best, and the grass inclined to be dwarfish, and although the surface is handsome yet for general beauty does not Compare with Illinois, Iowa or Eastern Nebraska - Saw a few rabbits and several Antelope [crossed out:  today] this morning:  At 8 oclock AM we crossed         [?North?] Platte which is nearly a half mile wide and stopped for Breakfast at the North Platte station a few yards beyond
  At each station aside from the Company buildings appear to be a few business houses generally of a temporary appearance - and nearly every house is a store hotel and whiskey shop combined
  But little building timber is to be found in the Country and buildings are often built of brush, adobes and dirt
  The Road continues up and

Saw several Emigrant trains Westward bound.  Saw Antelope at short intervals all day after noon dark & cloudy.  We gradually reached the tops of the high table lands, not rough, but gently rolling, with short grass and not a particle of wood of any kind and at 4 45 arrived at Chyenne [sic] the Capital of Wyoming Territory a pretty place situated on the elevated treeless plains & contains about 3000 inhabitants and is the junction of the UP & Denver Rail Road - AT 6 30 PM entered the Black Hills, generally appearing high rough & rocky   cold winds, snow in patches in the Canyons and north hill sides, antelope were plenty & not very wild and several of the passengers appeared to enjoy themselves in firing at them from the Car windows with Revolvers, it appeared to amuse the men while the Antelope were in no danger at all

   Was at Sherman at Sundown the highest summit of the Black hills and the highest point on the Pacific Rail Road
   At 8 oclock in the evening was at Laramie situated in the Laramie fork of Platte River where for a short time

62 
was experienced one of those terrible storms of rain, thunder and lightning for which the Platte River Country has been so long noted

  It rained so furiously that the water accumulated on the ground faster than it could run away and actually became several inches deep even on the sloping hills - We pass on.  It is night  Sleeping Cars are $6 per day, consequently the most of the passengers sleep and doze away their time in their seats, and it is also observed that the most of them have a satchel or carpet sack and have their own lunch
   Meals along the road are poor and $1 each

Friday June 4 1869
At daylight was at Station "Seperation" where the waters of the continent divide and run East to the Mississippi and West to the Pacific - A high plain, rolling and thick sage brush, light desert soil and but little water.  Morning dark & thick cloudy.  At 8 a.M stopped for Breakfast at "Bitter Creek" station on a small tributary of Green River:  Following down Bitter creek through a desolate region of country and reached Green River at 11 A.M. and here were detained until  3 P.M. in consequence of a train being off the track a

63
this down to the junction with the Weber River, thence down the Canyon of the Weber passing through several tunnels and at day break are at the Ogden city Depot about 3 miles from the city
Saturday Morning June 5 1869
At the Depot this morning we found a stage in waiting to convey passengers to Ogden City for $1 - per head, of course this opportunity was not allowed to pass by and soon was landed at the hotel in Ogden on the margin of the Great Salt Lake vally [sic] and in full view of the Lake which lies away to the westward over a low and level flat some 12 or 15 miles distant

  Immediately back of the town the Mountains are high and quite abrupt, and large snow banks still appear -
  We find vegetation much farther advanced than in Michigan a few days ago - Young peaches apples are the size of Robins eggs - From the Mountains to the Lake the Ground is generally level, fertile and the most of it occupied by settlers - The farming land is divided up into small farms or patches of 10 - 20 or 30 acres and by this system an accommodation is

not far ahead of us, and singular to relate that within a few rods of this very identical spot in Nov last we were detained nearly 24 hours from a similar cause - To day I have the honor of making the acquaintance of Hon H. M Corbett United States Senator from Oregon who was on his way home from Washington accompanied by his wife and other friends

   Fourteen miles further came to Bryan where I took the Cars in [?] last when on my way East - At 4 30 P.M. we were at Fort Bridges & stopped for supper
   From the various points along the Road, the snowy head tops of the Wahsatch Mountains are visible to the Southward 75 or 80 miles off:
   A small growth of shrubbery begins to appear along the streams and occasionally a Juniper tree is seen along the hills
   Soon passing over "Quaking Aspen" Summit we found a steep grade and short curves, and the Road generally in a bad and apparently unsafe condition: and at dark we find ourselves at Bear River and soon cross over another summit & enter Echo Canyon & follow

64
of all races but the majority being from Parents of forign [sic] birth
The Sunday School Catechism was peculiar and about as follows
Who was our first Prophet - (ans by all [?hands?]                     Joseph Smith
Was he a good man                                                                  Yes Sir
Was he a Christian                                                                    Yes Sir
Did he teach the word of God                                                    Yes Sir
Was he killed                                                                             Yes Sir
How was he killed                                                                      By a mob
Who was killed with him                                                             Prophet Hiram
Who was Joseph Smiths Sucessor                                            Brigham Young
Is he a good man                                                                       Yes Sir
Is he a prophet of the living God                                                 Yes Sir
Do you believe what Brigham Young does is right                       Yes Sir
Do you believe he is a christian                                                   Yes Sir
Is he good to the Church                                                            Yes Sir
When your parents send you to church you will not laugh
and talk will you                                                                           No Sir
When your Parents send you to school you will go there
and be quiet and obey your teachers wont you                            Yes Sir
and so on to an indefinite length  The questions being asked by one of the Superintendents and answered by the whole school at once

  The church building which by the way is tithing house, Fort, Ball room &c was crowded after the sabbath School was over and with several other travellers we went in to hear the word of God promulgated by these poor benighted heathens who are taught nothing

afforded to a much larger population - The dry climate necessitates irrigation which with a fertile soil and an industrious system of cultivation which has been adopted, an abundance of produce is generally secured from small patches of ground

   Grain of all kinds and fruits do splendid - Sorghum grows spontaneously and nearly every farmer manufactures their own syrup - Salt is obtained in any quantities from the Lake shore  Mormon Institutions flourish in a manner scarcely recognizable outside the Mormon jurisdiction
  Visited my Brother Lafayette and remained with him during the day

Sunday June 6 1869
Ogden City is presided over & run by Bishop West, a branch of the Mormon Church - Attended a Sabbath school in the forenoon and church in the afternoon & it was surprising to see what a vast number of little folks the place turns out on those occasions - between 2 & 300 small schollars [sic] were present at the Sabbath school which appeared to be well conducted & the children attentive - The children appeared from about 4 to 15 years old

65
Monday morning and join in the good work which the Lord has laid out for them to do and thus pay up their dues and every one else was invited to go at once and join with the church in the Morrow and aid in the Construction of the road, that they must trust in Providence and Brigham Young for their pay, at an unknown price, and at an unknown time 
That it was sufficient for the people to know that Brigham Young had ordained the Road to be built, that his orders must be obeyed, and that the people were expected to be on hand at the given time with all the apparatus for grading & making Rail Roads

   A full house in Utah developes [sic] many items of interest - Irish, Scotch - Norwegians - Dutch - French Canadians - English and Americans Make up the assemblage
  The  congregation consisted of Men and women of all ages & Conditions from Infant Babes to person 80 years of age & more -
  Perhaps a majority of the Men and women were dressed in homemade cloth clothes, others in a cheaper kind of Store clothes woolen or calicoes - But little jewelry or personal ornaments were seen and but few women wore hoops, and all were entirely destitute of waterfalls (poor things)

and in fact know nothing else but Mormonism in its worse forms - the intelligent class keeping the Masses in ignorance while the ignorent [sic] class have no ambition to advance beyon  [sic] the direct teachings of Brigham Young & his church Officials

  The meeting house was crowded and the audience seated by an Usher - A sort of pulpit was arranged in which was seated 12 men, and exhortations were delivered by several of them upon different subjects such as religion agriculture, Rail Road, &c.  While one of them a "Bishop" took it upon himself to define Mormonism and stated that the Mormon religion "contained everything that was good which we had any knowledge of besides a great deal we knew nothing about"
  We were willing to agree with him on that point
  Another subject was the Construction of the Utah Central Rail Road from the Union Pacific at Ogden City to Salt Lake City 
  An invitation was extended to all who had subscribed stock money or labor and all who wished to invest and all who happened to be owing back tithings to come forward on

their hair generally braided about their necks -

  Their habits of Matrimony allowing the marriage of near relatives has no good or beneficial effect upon their offspring
  Cousins, Uncles, Nephews, Aunts, nieces &c &c intermarry at pleasure, and the result of those incestuous Marriages has a hastening tendency towards degeneration
  In a conversation with Bishop Holmes after church, he remarked that a great outside "prejudice existed against Mormonism because they made polygamy a part of their religion, that it would be impossible to accomplish their object and keep up their church organization without it and that it was impracticable to abolish it"
  Theaters are very popular & dances are indulged in to a great extent:  Theaters and dances are always opened & closed with prayer

Monday June 7 1869
A cool and pleasant morning, a few of us had a curiosity to see how many people would "obey the invitation" (as a preacher said) and move out this morning to work on the Rail Road - We drifted along leisurely in that direction

expecting that perhaps a half dozen, a few more or less might be found [?will?] to respond to the orders of Brigham Young and commence on the Utah Branch of the Overland Rail Road

  We were surprised however to see a procession of nearly, if not quite a mile in length with teams, wagons, horses, mules, women, children & all the necessaries for Camping & living on the road:
  Men carried Shovels, picks, axes, crow bars, and all the necessaries for grading & chopping timber &c  Families had their tents. horsemen had their Lariats . and everything indicated that they were really in earnest and was ready to work at the word of Command

Tuesday June 8 1869
We went on board the cars last night at midnight . westward bound . and at daylight this morning we were at Promontory Point 60 miles from Ogden City

   This is the present terminus of the Union Pacific Rail Road & here the junction was formed with the Central Pacific on the 9 day of May last
   This point is situated in the Desert looking sage hills just North of the North end of Salt Lake.  the Lake however being entirely hidden by a low range of Mountains

[first line partly obscured by newspaper clippings]
The company [3 or more covered words] and last rail was celebrated on the 9th May 1869 - the last tie was made of California Laurel ornamented with Silver border . and figures and the last spike driven being of solid gold.  and driven with a Silver hammer:  The connection of the two roads was made about 100 yds west of the Depot and was visited by every body = The Laurel tie was immediately removed after the first train past over it a pine one substituted, and curiosity hunters were so eager to secure pieces therefrom that thereafter it had been entirely Cut away with Jack knives . and at present several wagon loads of ties are lying there and ready to be laid as soon as the other is chipped away:  For Convenience to that class, the Company appear disposed to render them all aid they well can, and have actually furnished an axe which is left there for the express purpose of cutting off Slivers from the last tie . upon some occasions it having been necessary to replace two or three ties per day, to supply the plans of  those despoiled

   Whiskey shops. Bawdy houses and Gambling saloons are all the go - Girls appear to be very numerous, and they generally

The Junction was formed at this point much against the wishes and Calculations of the C.P.R.R. Co.   Ogden City was the contemplated place of junction and an effort is now being made to have it removed to that place
The Promontory plain is level lying East and west between two considerable ridges or low mountains . with a scattering growth of small Juniper upon the hills.  otherwise no timber is visible anywhere. no water in the vicinity & that for general use must necessarily be hauled for several miles   the town like most all other uncertain places along the Road is built of tents & cloth . with occasionally a board house cut into squares, indicating that it had been moved from some other point

  In most all cases the Road Company have very good substantial buildings . good Depots and waiting rooms but at this point and at Ogden the Depot localities have not yet been fixed permanently . consequently none built and passengers in waiting are compelled to stand up or sit down in the sand or on top of a sage bush . thus rendering it very unpleasant in waiting

68
nearer and nearer to each other until the River & Road are almost crowded together when finally the Road bears off a little to the right and after passing a few unimportant stations we were at "Elko" a nice little town situated on a sandy level a few yards from the River . this place Contains a few wooden and perhaps 200 cloth houses and tents and contains a population of 6 or 700 .   this is important as the main point of departure for the White Pine silver mining Dist recently discovered about 75 miles south of here and which at the present time is attracting much attention

  Immediately south of town on the opposite side of the River rises a low range of Mountains covered with heavy sage and beyond in the far distance may be seen the white head tops of a range of Mts in the vicinity of the White Pine Mining Dist - while low sage hills extend to the north and as far as vision will extend
   We stopped at Elko for two hours and then rolled out and was soon at "Carlin" another similar town to Elko . and maintains its importance also as a place of departure for the White Pine Region
  At this point the R.R. company

appear as if they had passed a night of debauchery . one of them has a terribly black eye . and another has her hand bandaged up

  The day was hot. and at 1 P.M. the C.P. train was ready to start. and in a short time we passed out from behind the promontory hills in full view of the North Western portion of Salt Lake and for some time continued along and near the lake over level sage land with white, dry salt flats bordering the Lake:  We last saw the Lake at about 4 P.M. the road still traversing sage plains, entirely destitute of timber and water. somewhat hilly and at 9 PM. was at Montello station 67 miles from Promontory

Wednesday June 9 1869
Was at "Death" Station at daylight 113 miles from Promontory and upon the head waters of the Humboldt River in Nevada, a fine morning. high snowy Mts some 15 or 20 miles to the southward

  We are now following down a stream about 20 feet wide through a narrow level sage valley. ground white with alkali.  a thick growth of small willows along the stream the hills on each side approaching

have constructed some very nice and extensive buildings , generally of wood

  Soon after leaving Carlin we pass through a gorge where for a short distance the rocks on our right rise perpendicular for several hundred feet . after which we cross the River to the South side on a substantial wooden Bridge . the River at this place being about 50 yds wide   
  We continued down on left bank near the River and at noon was at "Argenta" and stopped 20 minutes for dinner
  Hon B. J. Burns formerly of Scottsburg Oregon, and an old acquaintance of mine came on board the Cars at this point bound for San francisco
  The afternoon was hot & passed away slowly.  The sage bottoms along the River at times appearing to lie 3 or 4 miles wide
  The C.P. R.R. thus far appears to lie very smooth track well laid . ties all sawed . the passenger Cars very neat and well furnished and everything appears to be much neater and more substantial every way than the  U.P.R.R
  At 4 20 P.M. was at the Station of "Winnemucca" 121 miles from Carlin and 324

69
miles from Sacremento City

  At 6 30 was at Humboldt station and stopped 30 minutes for supper   To the left about 6 miles away appears a Mountain Range with snow patches visible in every canyon and on the northern slopes & mining camps along their base  At this place a poor farmer has made an unsuccessful attempt to raise something in a field of 8 or 10 acres which he has fenced in with a sage brush fence . the ground had been plowed at . but nothing appears to be growing thereon . this was the first attempt at agriculture since leaving Salt Lake 
  We soon after crossed the Humboldt to the right bank again which stream runs a short distance farther and spreads out into a small Lake . long known as the "sink of the Humboldt" and loses itself in the sand

Thursday June 10 1869
At daylight was at "Boka" a small station on the Truckee River a small stream rising on the Eastern slope of the Sierra Nevada Mts and running off easterly and like the Humboldt eventually loses itself in some of the numerous lakes which have no outlets along

and near the eastern base of the Sierra Nevadas  this place is in the mountains & they appear high & rugged all around us and heavy pine timber everywhere:

  The road was up the Truckee a rapid stream about 30 or 40 feet wide and after leaving the Mts it winds its way North Easterly and empties in to Pyramid Lake with no outlet
  At Truckee City we find a Mountain town of about 30 houses country rough rocky & heavy timbered a vast amount of lumber & wood lining the road on each side for miles . which is shipped off to the treeless country to the East of us by the lumber trains
  Larger Rail Road buildings appear at this place than we have seen at any other point  The road passes up on the left side of the canyon of the river for two or three miles and then doubles itself and runs back on the opposite side rising all time when we enter the first tunnel of something near 300 yds where as we emerge from darkness to light we find ourselves on the side of a high mountain. with the celebrated "Donner Lake" immediately to our right and

70
far below us when we turn to the left along the Mountainside parallel to the Lake which is to all appearance about 3 miles long and perhaps a mile in width

  Upon this Lake at about the Middle and on the opposite side the Donner party of Emigrants suffered privations so great in the year 1845 that many of the poor unfortunates died of Starvation while the living were often obliged to subsist upon the bodies of their dead Comrades
  One woman of this unfortunate party of Suffering emigrants (now living I believe in Cal) actually kept herself alive by eating parts of her dead husband and children.
  At about the west end of this little Lake we enter the snowsheds and for several miles to the "Cisco" station the road is principally covered over . and thus shutting out the Grand Mountain scenery for which this part of the road is noted
  Snow is visible through the openings in the sides of these sheds . where it has piled up in huge banks as it has slid off from the roofs . while it may be seen at any imaginable depth in the Canyons for many hundred feet below us - At Cisco the

train stopped 15 minutes for breakfast . heavy pine forests prevailing - Cisco is at or about the main summit & from this point we descend at a rapid and tortuous route following down the sides of the Mountains, with deep Canyons and gorges thousands of feet below us leading into the Sacremento [sic] Valley : We pass through 13 tunnells [sic] & 23 miles of Snow sheds when we find ourselves far down on the Mountain side:

  At 8 32 A.M. arrive at Dutch flat an old and pretty much deserted mining town containing about 300 houses . with the country around it . the Mountain sides and canyons & gulches all dug up and washed out by Miners in search of gold - this is about as high up in the Mountains as it was found profitable for Miners
  Still descending we next arrive at Colfax apparently a brisk little town 54 miles from Sacremento l Day hot and still . no air stirring in the Canyons
  At 11 A.M. was at Auburn another small place in the foot hills, oak timber appearing mixed with the fir & pine

71

  Pine timber soon disappears & we are in the Sacremento Vally Country gently rolling & timber principally oak and scattering with little or no small shrubbery
  At 12 30 was at Roseville 18 miles from Sacremento - This is the Junction of the Overland Road with the Oregon branch road
  Country handsome, rolling  & open . scattering oak covering the hills - As we advance every station begins to be of more importance . and in fact assume the dignity of little towns - Farms & farm houses now appear in every direction - Wheat is ripe & much of it cut - while haying appears to be generally occupying the attention of farmers
  Stopped at Roseville 15 minutes for Dinner
  At 1 30 P.M. was at the Depot in Sacremento City the Capital of the great state of California where we stopped for the remainder of the day -
  Almost as soon as I set foot on terra firma I met an old acquaintance of mine by the name of Wright whom I had known in Eastern Oregon while I was soldiering in 1865&6
  We found in Market, corn beans, pears, cabbage, onions and other vegetables - and apples

Pears, strawberries &c
Friday June 11 1869
Bought tickets for Roseburg Oregon by the overland stage distance 400 miles . fare 45 in coin or 60 dollars in Green Backs - We left Sacremento at 6 30 A.M. direct back on the C.P.R.R.and at 7. oclock was at the junction at Roseburg where the [sic] took the Oregon Branch, by entering the [? M?] Carr, which is cut loose from the Main train at this place Arrived at Marysville at 9 30 A.M.  distance   40 miles from Sacremento.  Country rolling with scattering oak timber and settled everywhere.

 Day hot and a vast number of Jackass Rabbits were seen along the route of the Road - With an omnibus the Stage passengers were coming through town to the Depot of the Oroville Road . where we again set out and was at Oraville at noon where we took dinner . with an abundance of green Corn
  This is the present [page covered: terminal?]  of the Oregon Branch Rail and at one oclock P.M. we entered the stage of the overland company . which was [?formerly?]

72
full. and among the passengers was a long haired Celestial from Hong Kong . and an old and wrinkled and pockmarked nigger wench . Blacker than the ace of Spades. who gloried in the honorable name of the "Belle of Oraville" so she said.  She was certainly old enough and black enough . and dirty enough and smelled bad enough to inherit that name or some other.   Two of our fellow passengers had through tickets to Portland Ogn and the remainder were way passengers

  Marysville (back) is situated in the junction of the Yuba and Feather Rivers . perhaps about ¼ mile from the Mouth of Yuba but between the two Rivers . and our route from that Point thus far, has been up the Feather River . generally a short distance back . through the rolling oak hills -
  From Oroville which is a mining town of considerable importance . we proceed in the stage up River about ¼ mile and cross over to the opposite side in a ferry Boat and leave the River and the Road led off northward over rough [?] lands .  with a rocky surface:  Day hot, air still  Dust almost unbearable

but at 6 P.M. arrived at Chico a handsome little place of about 20 houses beautifully situated on a level plain

  This place is noted as being the residence of one of Californias old Pioneers Gen Bidwell - He has a large land grant at this point and has extensive grain fields, orchards and vineyards which at the present time present a beautiful appearance
  Ten thousand Acres of wheat in one level field almost ripe enough for the harvester was waving magnificently before us - An orchard & vineyard of a Corresponding size upon a different part of his Ranch
  This was a sight I had heard much of previously, but had never witnessed before
  Ten thousand acres of wavy yellow grain spread out like a sea before you in an agricultural panorama not soon to be forgotten
  The General although supposed to be very rich, is said to be somewhat embarrassed by one of the passengers who had known much of his history for the last 20 years

73

  He lives in a medium house not at all conspicuous, but very plain and ordinary
  At a little after dark we crossed the Sacremento River to the West side and soon entered the town of Tehama which contains a brisk population and perhaps about 500 in number

Saturday June 12 1869
Last night was one of those very hot and sultry nights so common in the Sacremento Valley but entirely unknown in Oregon  The dust was horrible and we suffered much from the heat

  At midnight we was at Red Bluffs. the head of navigation on the Sacremento River and there we got rid of our Nigger wench & chinaman
 At daylight this morning we found ourselves in the foot hills near the head of the Sacremento Valley . the country hilly, with an abundance of timber and bush with a lively display of quails and Rabbits at every turn of the Road
  At 8 AM we was at Shasta City an almost deserted mining town which sprung up in 1852 . situated in the hills . with one main street and close blocks of buildings on each side .  The town is about ¼ mile long, but only a few

74
daylight we was at Callahans Ranch on the north side of Scotts Mountain another high Mountain over which the road passes .  similar in character to Trinity Mountain [crossed out:  We had breakfast at the station at the foot of the Mountain] and passing along through Scotts Valley, a handsome little farming locality . we soon arrive at a little town of 20 or 30 houses called Fort Jones where we took breakfast

 From this point the Road passes through little valleys and narrow Canyons, and over another high timbered Mountain into Shasta River valley and by a good road reached Yreaka the County Seat of Siskiyou County at 10 a.m. - This is a City of some little importance situated in a beautiful little valley or basin entirely surrounded by Mountains: Much mining has been done around and near here . Was settled in 1851 and has maintained its standing as a first class mining town ever since . The valley land around about here is in a high state of cultivation:  Passing Yreka about 20 miles we reach Klamath River which is about 80 yards wide & cross over in a ferry boat
  Mount Shasta one of the highest snowy peaks in the Siera [sic] Nevada Mountains is looming up against the

of he many buildings appear to be occupied!  We had a fair Breakfast at this place and soon after struck Slate Creek a tributary of the Sacremento River . and followed up stream in a Northerly Course when at about 1 P.M. we was at the foot of Trinity Mountain which we gradually ascend by an easy grade for about 7 miles to its summit & descend at a furious rate down a splendid grade for about 5 miles to its  base where we take supper at 4 PM.

 Continuing our north course we cross Trinity River abut 50 yds wide at a ford and follow up Stream through a heavy timber passing occasional Mining Camps to Trinity Center, an old but yet very small town of only a few houses situated in the thick woods - It is a Mining town and has for many years maintained its existence and support by the mining trade
  Passing Trinity Center night soon set in

Sunday June 13 1869
The night was cool, the road fair considering the general rough mountainous character of the Country.  This morning at

75
Small Pox had raged for several weeks at Jacksonville and about 40 persons had fallen victim to the fatal scourge and among the number Col T. Vault -

  He was an old pioneer of 1856 and although a man of dissipated habits, yet he had a naturally kind and open heart:  And while all the blame of our unfortunate affair on Sept 14 1851 was directly attributable to him, yet it was with sad feelings that I listened to the tale of his death from a loathsome disease, buried in the night with not a mourner to follow him to the grave:  If any difference actually appeared more sad to me than if he had died by the hand of the barbarians of the Coast on the aforesaid 14 Sept 1851
  We rested at Jacksonville until 4 oclock this morning when we was again under way passing through a fine valley of good prarie land and timber alternating . with evidence of gold mining visible upon every little stream & in every ravine and at 8 oclock crossed Rogue River on a bridge at Rock Point & took breakfast at the hotel. which together with a dwelling or two constitutes the town

Blue sky about 40 miles to the Eastward:  following over a rough route over a hilly country about 8 miles from the Klamath River we cross the line between California & Oregon being Lat 42 [degree mark] North .  Gradually ascending we soon reach the summit of the Siskiyou Mountains and by a rapid descent through a dense fir forest over a good grade we find ourselves at the foot of the Mountains in the Rogue River Valley -

  We passed down the valley of Bear creek a tributary of Rogue River in a North Westerly course through a handsome farming & agricultural country through Ashland and Gassburg and arrived at Jacksonville the County seat of Jackson County at 10 oclock P.M.  Evening rainy

Monday June 14 1869
Jacksonville had for many years been the residence & home of W. G. T. Vault, who had charge of the unfortunate party which was so near annhilated [sic] at the Mouth of the Coquille River in Sept 1851 and from which I escaped with my severe and very near Mortal wounds - during the past winter the much dreaded disease

[Picture torn from book or newspaper showing three snow-covered mountains, an encampment of four tepees]
Caption:  The Three Sisters in Cascade Range Oregon

From this place we follow down the River 6 or 8 miles along & near it through timbered country generally and thence bore off More northerly through a rough and heavy timbered region and at noon was at Grave Creek & took dinner at the Station kept by Mr. Harkness an old acquaintance of Mine
  We soon after crossed Wolf Creek tributary to Grave Creek thence over a high timbered divide the south line of [crossed out: between] Douglas [?Couglas?] County and descend to Cow Creek a tributary of the Umpqua River . following up this stream north easterly about 5 miles we are at the head of the "Big Canyon as it is called . thence 12 miles descending northerly over a good toll road and we emerge from the dark Canyon of Mountains & heavy timber to the open vally of the South Umpqua River and 1/4 mile further are at Canyonville . where we take supper:  At this place I am personally acquainted with nearly everyone, and actually consider myself at home
 Three miles from Canyonville we cross the [?North?] Umpqua River on a toll Bridge, thence down stream upon the right bank

through handsome and thickly settled vallys and arrived at Roseburg the County seat of Douglas County at 3 oclock at night where my travelling for the present terminates

Sunday July 25 1869
The celebrated humbug George Francis Train made a speech to a crowded house this afternoon at 4 oclock

  His speech or lecture was not taken down but a similar one published a few days later at Jacksonville is hereto appended

Saturday Aug 7 1869
Great Eclipse of the sun . about 3/4 obscured . said to be the last great eclipse of the Century
Sept 15 1869
Hon Schuyler Colfax Vice President of the United States and lady - Ex Governor Bross and Samuel Bowles of Illinois arrive on the stage from the North at 8 20 P.M. and tarried with us about 3 hours =

   The Vice President made a pleasant speech at the Metropolitan Hotel which had been previously brilliantly illuminated
  The distinguished visitors took their departure to the southward at 11 oclock in the evening

June 25 1869

  Upon my departure to the States . arrangements were made between myself and [?Mr?] Melvin the County Clerk for me to return at as early a date as practicable and assist in the performance of his arduous duties during the remainder of his term and a fair rate of Compensation previously agreed upon but upon my return I found he had made other arrangements very much to my disappointment
  However today I was employed to work in the W.S. Law Office at a fair salary where I shall probably remain for the present

Thursday July 1 1869
John Kelly former Register retiring from office today & [? W R Prelis?] succeeding him
Sunday July 4 1871
[?Amid?] firing in Town all day

Saturday Feb 26 1870
A small steamer having been built at the Mouth of the Umpqua River to try experiment of navigating the River as far as this place l today arrived in sight and was greeted by 
[?Armie?] firing and the wild huzzas of hundreds of our citizens -

  The stage of water was low and the boat had been about two weeks in working its way up . distance by the windings of the River about 100 miles -
  She was brought up by a crew of about 25 the best boatmen and labors to be found in the lumber wood along the coast . was actually drawn over 31 different rapids . and upon its arrival at Roseburg was much shattered and bruised

Sunday Feb 27 1870
The Steamer today loaded down with men women and children made an excursion up River about a mile above town to the first rapid but was obliged to return -

78
Monday Feb 28 1870
The Steamer set out on [torn page:?its time?] to day several persons going down . and among the passengers was Mrs. Lizzie Slocum who proposed to avail herself of this novel opportunity to visit her Parents 10 miles above Scottsburg - The Boat made the return trip in safety and in about 2 days . but run a very narrow risk upon the Rapids near the Trenton Ferry and barely escaped going to destruction

NOTES AT LARGE

  CALIFORNIA was first discovered in 1542, by a Portuguese, Juan R. Cabrillo, while in the Spanish service.  It was held by the Spanish, then by the Mexican governments, until 1848, when by treaty it became a portion of the United States.  It was admitted as a State in 1850.  It covers an area of 160,000 square miles, divided about equally into mining, agricultural, timber, and grazing lands.  All kinds of grain, fruit, and vegetables, grow in profusion.  The grape culture has occupied the attention of many of her people, who find that they can produce

May 18 1871

      Again set out for a visit to the States via the Overland Rail Road . My route was to Sacremento City Cal by Stage . thence by the C.P.R.R. to Ogden City - Utah . and thence to Omaha Nebraska by the W.P. R.R. there to Chicago by the Chicago and Rock Island route, thence to Detroit by the Michigan Central R.R. thence to Grand Blanc Michigan by the Detroit & Milwaukee R.R. the home of my youth where I arrived in about ten days  time
  Remained at Grand Blanc until the 5th July when I set out on my return . by very nearly the same route & arrived at Roseburg on the 17 July 1871 and in connection with Hon H. R. Fling I took the field as a Government surveyor of public lands in Douglas & Goose Counties Oregon & worked until the 20 of Nov . when I returned to Roseburg to pass the winter

    During the summer I surveyed a portion of the Coquille River over which I passed in 1851 . including the place of our encampment of the 13th Sept of that year . the night preceding the fight near the mouth of the River

Dear Sir.

Very respectfully
Yours
H.P. Baldwin

In March 1872 the political Campaign coming in I was selected as Candidate of the Republican party for County Clerk . an office which I had several times filled
