A continual firing was kept up by the advancing soldiers. but at last were repulsed and obliged to leave their dead and a portion of the wounded to fall into the hands of the Indians - The Indians generally concealed fired with fearful effect . while it was not known that an Indian was killed in the action

   Thus ends the second chapter of Modoc war

  The Modocs plundered & robbed the dead and tortured the wounded.  made raids upon the settlers for Beef. and upon packers and others for Guns and Ammunition . Emboldened by their success . appeared to be really invincible in the lava beds
   Army Contractors . speculators and newspaper Correspondents flocked there from every direction and by a wholesale system of lying . false and sensational Reports were put in circulation through the press and otherwise and Capt Jack and his little band (never over forty) of renegades worm eating Digger Indians became world wide renowned
  The press and a large portion of the people of California took sides with the miserable vagabond murderers . that they were

The Modoc War
On Nov 28 1872

         The Indian Dept aided by U. S. Soldiers attempted to remove Capt Jacks Band of 40 renegade Modoc Indians on to the reservation near Klamath Lake in south eastern Oregon - The Indians refused to go . and a fight was brought and much firing was done & the Indians [?] to the Mts killing about 17 settlers on their way -
        One or two soldiers were killed and a few wounded . while it is not positively known that a single Indian was killed . although more were reported killed than was actually in the engagement -
      This was the first chapter of the history of the Modoc war.

   The Indians fled and took their position in a [?scope?] of rocky County known as the lava beds.  where they remained undisturbed until about Jan 17 1873 . when the US Troops & citizens amounting in all to about 600 . moved upon the Indians in the rocks, and a fight ensued which lasted all day. resulting in the killing and wounding of about 40 men while the Indians dodging from rock to rock . were seldom if ever seen by the soldiers

89
around them the hosts of Indian sympathisers in and around Washington and inaugurated . or originated the Peace policy (as it has been called) by which the President through the Indian Dept should appoint a board of Peace Commissioners to treat with the murderous Modocs and that all hostilities should cease until the labors of the Commission were ended . The programme was submitted to the President who consented to adopt it . and at once a Commission was appointed

  While we have the greatest confidence and respect for Genl Grant . and while we believe him to be the proper person to ocupy [sic] the presidential chair . while we concede that his Mistakes are few in number and unimportant in character in Comparison the the [sic] errors and blunders of other presidents, yet his want of knowledge of the actual Condition of things in the Modoc country just at this time caused him to give way to his better judgment to satisfy the clamor of he Eastern people and appoint a "Peace Commission" which unquestionably was the greatest blunder he ever made during the whole of his exciting and eventful career . For that error Gen Grant is not to blame - The parties who falsely represented Oregon at the National Capitol . and who were

fearfully abused, that the whites were the aggressors and the only ones to blame  &c, and thus those wandering . fanatical and addle-brained Bohemian Correspondents with their sensations . lies and glittering falsehoods . created an impression upon the minds of the people in the older and more thickly populated states adverse to the punishment of those Indians which led to murder . bloodshed treachery, destruction of property and an expenditure of Millions of dollars . which might been avoided had better Counsel prevailed

  When the news of the outbreak and the subsequent repulse of the troops . reached Washington City unfortunately for the border settlers there happened to be in that City the Hon A. B. Meacham an Ex Supt of Indian Affairs and Hon E. S. Applegate Ex Surveyor General, those two distinguished persons had been superceded in their positions, and went to Washington for some purpose & happened to be there when the Modoc War Commenced
  By their united effort, and by a system of wholesale Mis representation . they succeeded in rallying

Instrumental in creating the Peace Commission are the same parties responsible therefor . upon their heads falls the blame & for Generations yet to come Curses will be heaped upon them by the outraged people of the frontiers

   Meacham was appointed upon the Commission as Chairman in Connection with a Mr. Case An Indian Agent, and the Hon Jesse Applegate an old pioneer of Oregon
  They proceded to the Modoc Country . and by the aid of a few (friendly) squaws who were living with white men were enabled to open a direct Communication with the Indians who still occupied the Lava beds -
  Applegate having had a great deal of experience in Oregon with Indians . and understanding their Character, soon saw the folly of the course adopted. finding the same to be a failure . withdrew from the Commission in disgust pronouncing the same a failure and an "expensive blunder"
  Mr. Case soon after left in disgust and went to his peaceable Indians on their reservation in the North part of the State
  Meacham had lost his position as superintendant of Indian affairs  He was [?abitious?] to redeem himself

in the eyes of the Government somehow and clung to his peace policy as it is called in hopes that something might be accomplished by which he could be reinstated or get an Agency at least

  L. S. Dyer another Agent of a distant friendly tribe . and Judge Roseborough of Yreka a Mountain town of California . and Elijah Steele of the same place . were now appointed upon the peace Commission and proceeded to the Indian country to negotiate a treaty with 30 or 40 murderous Digger Indians who had  their head quarters in the rock on South side of Tule Lake  Judge Roseborough was and [sic} Indian sympathizer . and a great friend of the Modocs . In him they had Great Confidence
  Steele is a Lawyer by profession has been in warm sympathy with the Modocs ever since the war began , has run with them for the last 20 years . is their legal adviser , and by his Counsel and advice the Indians refused to go on to the reservation in Nov and as a choice commence a Warfare against the whites . which thus far has proved expensive and disastrous . and the loss of life has been great in Comparison to the numbers engaged

91
upon the peace Commission, and in Connection with Meacham and Dyer . soon entered upon their duty

  Canby was a venerable man.  An old Army Officer . fought through the Mexican War . and was an efficient General and gained high renown during the war of 1861-5 had been much on the frontiers & was supposed to have a pretty general knowledge of Indian character
  Dr. Thomas was a Christian Man . had but one object in view and that was to do all the good it was possible for him to do in this life -
  I was a travelling Companion of his at one time for 2 days in a stage - He was a pleasant man.  very pious.  anxious to do good to all, A true Christian, was enthusiastic upon the Indian question which we discussed much of the time - We Could agree pretty well on most all other questions, but upon this we widely differed - He was for Christianizing them while I was a firm believer in total annihilation.  He often referred to the poor abused Indians . while I held that an Indian Could not be abused - Like a celebrated Chief Justice I occupied the position that an Indian had no rights which a white man was bound to respect

Roseborough and Steel went into the Indian strong hold and remained a sufficient time to satisfy them that the peace business was a failure and then abandoned the Commission & returned to Yreka

  The Jackson County Circuit Court had been in session during the winter of 1872&3 and Indictments were found against all the Indians who engaged in the murders on Lost River near the Oregon boundary in Nov 1872
  While such action, might been[sic] proper under Certain other Circumstances, yet at this particular time may have done harm . for the Mission of Steele to the Indian strong hold, appears to have been to post the Indians in regard to the Indictments in Jackson Co Ogn and that if they surrendered they would be arrested & hung
  The fear of the Civil law and other reasons . unquestionably Caused those Indians to become more desparate  [sic] than they otherwise would
  Soon after this, Rev. Eleasar Thomas of California and Gen E. R. S. Canby of the U.S. [concealed by page turn ?Army?] In command of the Dept of the Columbia . of which Oregon forms a part, was appointed

He frequently spoke of the honor of an Indian . while my position was, that if an Indian ever acted honorable it was when he meditated treachery or murder

  How fearfully true this last proved in his case in 1873 
  The reconstructed peace Commission entered upon their duties in February 1873 . and after a long and tedious attempt at reconciling the Indians . and after it had become a notorious fact that during the entire negotiations the Indians were intriguing for their Capture . and after being cautioned by all to be vigilant and watchful, Yet on April 11 1873 they were entrapped and Canby and Thomas Murdered . and Meacham badly wounded . while Dyer by a fortunate Combination of Circumstances escaped
  Thus fell two splendid men . Victims of the basest act of treachery on record -
   Canby had full charge of the Commission . he was a man universally liked every where . his life was a part of the history of the U.S.  He had become famous as a soldier . he was cool in time of danger and wise in the Counsel rooms . his judgment was generally

respected . he made fewer mistakes than any other person of his experience . but at last fell a victim to his own bad judgment - His lack of proper judgment at this particular time cost him his life - It will not aid or add to his former brilliant reputation as a soldier . His loss is mourned by the whole nation - His friends will ever regret that he accepted the fatal mission . better far if he had been killed by a rebel bullet during the Rebellion of 86& 5 in which he took so active a part

  The Rev Dr Thomas was an enthusiast . he had all confidence in the honor of an Indian . he could not have known much of their treacherous disposition . his idea was that a prayer book would have a much more soothing influence over the savage mind than a Henry Rifle -  How unfortunate & fatal the position
  This Act of Treachery and Murder will have a beneficial effect upon the Government . It will weaken the peace policy with Armed forces of hostile Indians  It will teach Uncle Sam that a little less hymnbook policy and a little more Henry Rifle policy is by far the best policy for the [?.....tution?]

of our extended unprotected border settlements

 Immediately after the Comms were butchered, an attack was made by Genl Gillem upon the Indians in their Rocky retreat from which by the aid of Cannon &c they were soon dislodged

On April 26th 1873, a strong party of about 70 men well officered were sent out and were ambushed by the Modocs who probably not exceed 15 or 20 and out of the whole command only about 24 escaped injury  
  Capt Jack fought this battle with Gen Canlys uniform on
  The officers in command of this scout were brave unto death. but had no knowledge whatever of Indians, or they would not been so completely entrapped
  From an observatory at Hd Quarters , the Commotion of the battle was seen . and strange to relate no effort was made to Communicate with the troops or to send them relief . It is probable that the massacre might been prevented had the proper kind of brains been in Command  at hdQrs Gen Gillem was in Command and, at least should be censured for his careless indifference

The Volunteers or some other disguised parties  on June 7 1873 waylaid a Wagon which was Carrying Indian prisoners from one point to another and killed four of Modocs.
  This is the outrage, and it is expected that another howl of indignation will go up from the Indian sypathises [sic] of the East :  This murder of Indian prisoners is Condemned by All
  It is safe to say that those who perpetrated the act kept a safe distance from the Indians while the war was going on
  Had the Volunteers or Citizens organized a programme and acted in Concert with each other, and at a given time taken possession of [underlined: All] the Modoc prisoners and hung them the people of the west without a dissenting voice would have said [underlined: Amen] to it

Roseburg Oregon Sept 26th 1873
Desiring a little recreation from the busy scenes of Office life . I concluded I would make a trip to Ft Klamiath to Witness the hanging of the condemned Modocs

  Started from Roseburg at 8.P.M. on the Oregon and California stage leaving C.C. Slocum in charge of the Clerks office

Sat Sept 27 1873
Last night was quite chilly. and the roads dry and very dusty. we passed through the little town of Myrtle Creek 15 Miles . Canyonville 12 Miles further.  thence through the Canyon. to Cow Creek station about 12 Miles further - At daylight was on the summit of the Cow Creek hill the dividing range between the waters of the Umpqua & Rogue Rivers . and also the County line between Douglas and Josephine Countys - Took breakfast at Grove[?Forest?] and found the Comforts of a good fire in addition to a good Meal of victuals

  Dinner at Rock Point in Rogue River where we cross over on a Bridge to the southside Course of River about West and rocky and rapid at this place  Reached Jacksonville at 3:30 P.M. & put up at Horns Hotel

102
[?Bylers?] Ferry. course of stream about West low banks and level Country on each side . stream about 125 yards wide , Our course was up the River . over rooling [sic] table lands. generally back therefrom some little distance and stopped for the night with an isolated family 32 miles from Jacksonville . we fare well & slept out doors
Wednesday [crossed out: Sept 30] October 1 1873
We have already left the main settlements and now only now and then see a house where someone has settled down. thinking to make a litle [sic] something off the travel on the Road from the Vally to the Ft Klamath - Road hilly today and rocky in places . yet fair for a mountain road - At about 2 oclock P.M. we Came down out of Mts and crossed RRiver to the opposite side upon a Bridge which had been thrown across a rocky gorge where the River narrowed to about 15 yds in width . course of River nearly south - From this crossing we passed through a section of heavy timbered land, and at 11 miles came to a famouse [sic] Camp ground known as Union Creek having travelled about 30 miles

  Union Creek is a stream about 30 feet wide runs West into Rogue

Sunday Sept 28, 1873
Remained in Jacksonville
Monday Sept 29 1873
Remained in Jacksonville
Tuesday Sept  30th 1873

  This morning had been fixed upon for our start to Cross over the Cascade Range of Mts to the Fort, our Company was Made up of Jones an old Stage Driver . Cunninghorn Dr H.Helms saloon keeper all of Jacksonville , W. C. Griswold a Claim Agent and speculator of Salem Oregon and myself -
  A very good wagon road extends from here to the Fort . and it was agreed that the easiest and Most Comfortable means of traveling was to hire a hack & 4 horses which was done for the sum of $20 each
  We set out in good spirits as such fellows . upon such an occasion generally do
  Our Course was about N.E. over a level country . settled and reasonably well improved timber & prarie alternating.  Crossed Bear Creek running a N.W. course . and at about 14 miles crossed Rogue River at

103
-ually descended with a deep canyon to our left . with perpendicular cliffs in which we could hear the roaring of falling waters. as they rushed Eastward to find their outlet into the Klamath Lakes

   At about 10 Miles from the Summit we enter open level prarie lands with Groves of spruce & yellow pine alternating . and about  5 miles further are at the Fort at 3 PM Distance about 100 miles . course from Jacksonville to the Summit of the Cascades about N.E & from the Summit to the Fort about S.E.
  Ft Klamath is beautifully located upon the right on West bank of Fort Creek, another beautiful stream of transparent water running South - It is about 25 yards wide level banks, timber along and immediately bordering it - The fort situated amongst the scattering timber overlooking a wide expanse of level prarie or Meadow land to the Westward, terminating with thick timber a few miles away , with the rugged Cascades in the back ground and the towering "peak" Mt McLaughlin in a Course about S.W. from us
 In the Mountains the soil is generally of a light pumice stone

River only a short distance off  The stream is rapid & clear in fact is one of those pure and transparent streams peculiar to this Mountain region - Colder than Ice water - so transparent that where the water is quiet it is scarcely noticeable at first sight - Banks low & level . timber Pine . fir. &c
Thursday Feb 2d 1873

     We set out quite early   Morning Cold & frosty . gradually ascending . a short distance from Camp touch upon Rogue River and then leave it for good . We pass over a large extent of burnt land with green timber alternately and at 12 Miles reach a low pass which is the summit of the Cascade Range of Mts
  In Crossing the Cascades from West to East it is generally calculated that the labors of the trip are pretty much over when the summit is reached
  Timber after summit is evergreen.  Pine, fir, spruce pine &c

While the foregoing description of these Executions is not written in quite as Glowing terms as appears by the reports of the several Newspaper Correspondents present, yet it is equally as true

  Six Indians had been condemned - Dispatches were made public this morning that two of them "Barncho" and "Slolux" had been reprieved and sentenced to hard labor at Alcatraz for life
  Those two were present at the time of the Murder of the Peace Commissioners but it was not proven that they took any part in the killing
  The Commutation of their sentence left 2 ropes hanging loosely and two graves unfilled

  Several of the other Modocs who were prisoners, but had the liberty of the Garrison Grounds were present, such as "Scarfaced Charly" - "Bogus Charly" - "Hooka Jim: - "SteamBoat Frank" and "Shacknasty Jim" who deserted Capt Jack and offered their services to General Davis, and who actually turned traitor to Jacks Command, and hunted him down and Captured the remnant of his little Band were present but just before the Execution were placed inside the Stockade, where the remainder of the Modoc prisoners were confined

and the [?teaming?] with heavy fright [sic] wagons has Ground the dust to several inches in depth and renders riding in a wagon very unpleasant and disagreable
Friday Oct 3d 1873

 This is the day fixed upon by the War Department for the hanging of the Modoc Indian Murderers - the morning was clear & bright frosty -  At Guard Mount the whole Garrison of four Companies were under Arms 
  A large Concourse of Citizens were present, and several hunched Indians from the Klamath Reservation
  The hour of execution had arrived - Punctual at 10 oclock Capt Jack - Schonchin . Black Jim and Boston Charley stepped upon the Schaffold [sic]  - A few delicate adjustments were Made about their necks . when suddenly the platform gave way and their souls dropped into Hell but their bodies stopped short at the lower end of the ropes - A few more Indians and the Modoc hanging would been a complete and brilliant success

Amounting in All . Men . women & Children to about 60 persons all told - Those first named were the best of Jacks warriors, other prisoners of less note were Manacled and kept inside the Stockade

  Capt Jack happened to be the so called Chief of the Modocs  At the time the Modoc business Commenced 
  He run into the Lava beds with the remainder of the Indians - The bravest and most efficient warriors were those previously mentioned as deserting Jack and offering their services to General Davis - They done all the killing, and furnished all the brains and Generalship of the Modoc war and Capt Jack got all the Credit & fame - Hence they deserted  him - Jack was not a brave Indian . he was often accused of Cowardice by his own men.  He denied that he Killed Gen Canby . Boston Charly claimed that honor Jack begged for his life and wished to have Scarfaced Charly executed in his place -  When the Priest was picturing to him in glowing colors all the beauties of the happy hunting grounds . he stopped him short and offered him ten horses if he would talke [sic] his place - He dropped down upon his

Thus has ended the Modoc war. a [?terrifling?] affair . which was manipulated into a great and national importance by the Sensational Newspaper Reporters who agitated the [?] and [?] Indians to such an extent that another Month and we would have had a general Indian War. reaching from Mexico to British Columbia
  They are more responsible for the Modoc war than any other Class . and had justice been done they would been placed in the front ranks in the time of Danger , and been Manacled or in the Guard house after it had passed

Trip to Coose Bay & Coquille River
1874 Aug 6

   Set out from Roseburg to Coose Bay and the Coquille River on a visit and to once more  examine the Grounds over which our little party of adventurers passed in 1851 .

also the battle ground and the route over which my comrad [sic] Hiddan & myself passed after the fight

  Left Roseburg at 5 AM in the Coose Bay Stage. and crossed the South Umpqua River at the ford at the West part of Town . and pursued our route in a South Westerly direction through Looking Glass Valey and  a part of Ten Mile with praries and timbered ridges alternating thickly settled , and at 10 30 arrived at the foot of the Coast Range Mts about 18 Miles from Roseburg
   The Mountain was of heavy timber, badly burned . sleety . but a very good grade for a wagon Road Made by the Coose Bay Wagon Road Company; By the winding of the Road . it is about 3 miles from base to summit;
  At the summit we stop for Dinner at Mr J.D. Smiths. The Stage proprietor who has established a station at this point = This Road from

July 8th 1874

  My term as County Clerk having expired this day , I retired from the position and turned over the affairs of the Office to my successor

Friday August 7 1874
Set out early.  and in about 2 miles passed "Brewsters" claim after which the Vally has been named - Brewster being the first settler in this vally . and being the original projector of the Coose Bay Wagon Road

  A short distance farther we leave the bottom land . and pass over a Narrow grade several hundred feet above the River (on our left) and soon after enter upon [crossed out: More] land of a more hilly . than Mountainous Nature heavy timber passing several streams running to our left tributary to the [?North?] Fork . upon which settlements appear . when at noon we reach the [?North?] Fork cross the same on a Bridge and soon stop for Dinner at "[?]" at the N.W. side of [marked X for insert] "Burton Prarie"
 The North Fork of the Coquille at this place is about 50 feet wide flows south through a heavy timbered Country. With fine bottoms of myrtle & Maple land, mostly claimed by settlers, who are chopping out homes for themselves and families. where a vast amount of labor is required . to open up a farm - $50 and upwards is often paid per acre for clearing

[Written in left margin for insert at X]
X  Burton an early settler Killed by Indians in 1853 near this place, hence the name

Roseburg to Coose Bay was opened in 1870&71by an organization called the "Coose Bay Wagon Road Co" who obtained a grant of land from Congress and opened a fair mountain Road . upon which a weekly line of stages were soon placed and the business increasing to some extent , At the present time are run Triweekly   Fare $8.00.  63 miles

  Set out after dinner and at once began the descent of a Canyon . tributary with Coquille River it having what is known as the East Fork of the North Fork of the Coquille -  
  We follow this Canyon with a rapid stream of pure water . high abrupt mountains on each side . and a dense growth of large green timber of Fir, hemlock & Cedar with the usual variety of undergrowth . peculiar to the Oregon mountains . for a distance of about 12 miles when one enter Brewster Vally narrow bottoms of Myrtle & Maple timber . and claimed by settlers - At the second house Mr. Flooks . we arrive at dark and put up for the night

Saturday August 8 1854

   Marshfield Contains about 40 buildings all told including a steam saw mill - Is situated at the head of Coose Bay . near the junction of Coose River - Catching slough - Isthmus slough and Coal bank slough - and is likely to become a place of considerable importance upon the Bay - It is principly situated upon Tide lands or Mud flats. with poor arrangements as to streets . wharves or walks . with a few nice residences and buildings in the foot hills immediately back of it - The title to the land upon which the town is built has been litigated for several years and the question is not yet settled . hence the prosperity of the town has been considerably checked
  At 1 PM Capt Maltson launched a fine vessel which had been built at this place for the Oregon & California trade.  the launching was witnessed by a large concourse of citizens from the different points on the Bay - The colors at the Masthead announced the name "Freitchioff"
  In the PM went on board the steamer "Messenger" for Empire City and after a run down the Coast north about 4 miles we halted at "North Bend" where the enterprising "Simpson Bros" have a large   steam mill & shipyard where the largest vessel ever built on

Leaving [?] at about 11 oclock P.M. we continued about 6 miles through heavy timbered hills to the head of Catching slough so called from [?] Catching the first settler thereon -

  At this point Hon J. B. Deelly Representative elect from Coose County has recently laid out a town called "Summer" and H. H. Luse the pioneer Capitalist of Empire City on Coose Bay is building a small steamer to run upon the Bay and to navigate the Catching slough Waters place - the place now contains a store and three or four other temporary buildings
  From this point the road leads up a high timbered mountain to a summit ridge between Catching slough and Isthmus slough thence in a NorthWesterly course along said summit to its descent to Bay City a new point at the Mouth of Isthmus slough opposite Marshfield - this town has but recently been laid out, by Mr. D. McKay: only one house at present - It is about a half mile across to Marshfield & McKay took the passengers over in a Row Boat and all put up for the night at Rogers Hotel

Monday August      10 1874
Went on Board the Steamer "Satellite" for a trip up the Bay. touched at North Bend and Marshfield & entered the Isthmus Slough which followed up stream about 6 miles to Coose City on the left a place of two houses

  A mile or so further on on [sic] the left side is Henryville . a point where a new coal Mine is to be opened - The ground is hilly to the waters edge - the hills are being cleared off, and numerous new buildings are in course of construction and everything seems to indicate success - About 3 miles further & we are at the "Isthmus" so called from its position between the Isthmus slough of Coose Bay and the Beaver slough of the Coquille River - This is the head of Navigation , and from this point to the navigable water of Beaver slough an old Tramway or horse Rail Road for about 3 miles has been in operating for several years, to Convey freight & supplies . from Coose Bay to the settlements on the Coquille River
  A new Rail Road (narrow guage [sic]) is now building from a point about 2 Miles below the Isthmus to a pint near Beaver slough where a new Coal Mine called the "Blue Mountain" Mine is about

this coast is now in course of construction - Leaving North Bend we soon round the point and turn West for a mile or so and then South about 5 miles to Empire City the oldest Town on the Bay and the County seat of Coose County - Empire City has its Steam Saw Mill, its stores. several Hotels, saloons & other buildings and a New Custom house

   Coose County as first permanently settled in  1850 by an organization called the "Coose Bay Company" - The Co was composed of Men with but little capital . and while they were unable to do much towards building up the place . or developing its resources of timber and Coal . yet they talked it into considerable importance, so much that capitalists turned their attention to the place and in 1855 two large steam saw mills & one or two coal Banks were put in operation - & from that time to the present Coose Bay & its surroundings has gradually grown in importance until the present time - The timber in the Mts and the heavy deposits of Coal seem to be almost inexhaustible while the very limited amount of farm land upon the Bay and its tributaries yield an abundance of agricultural products

Court house and printing office

to be opened - When completed to that point it is proposed to build it to the Coquille River about 3 miles further - which will materially aid in the transportation business from the Coquille Vally to the shipping points in Coose Bay -

    Walked over the old Rail Road Track . passing a new steam mill and was soon at the head of the [?Bearer?] slough -  crossed over the Marsh to the West and followed a poor trail down to the Coquille River at the Mouth of the slough arriving there at about 3 oclock P.M
  Here I obtained a row boat and the Tide being down stream I set out down river and at at [sic] 8:30 PM I landed at Stewarts on the right bank and put up for the night

Tuesday August 11 1874
Set out early on a down River tide and at about 10 A.M. was at the point on the right bank where we had the fight with the Indians on 14 Sept 1851. when 5 men were killed and myself so severely wounded that I was unable to take care of myself . for 8 years

  I landed upon the Bank and carefully examined the premises  All looked perfectly familiar

113
and the exact point of attack was readily recognized as well as the route of the fight by me across the Marsh for about ½ mile from where the fight began to the place where it finally terminated - the land is now owned by John Lewis who lives above and back from the River - 

   Instead of Marble Monuments to Mark the place of this sanguinary Conflict, or to tell the tale of the bloody masacre [sic] , or to indicate to the traveller the place where those heroic pioneers fell you see a fine field of potatoes growing luxuriantly and in full bloom
  After contemplating the scene of this early and melancholy event I proceeded down the River about a Mile and stopped at Mr. John Hamblocks . who with his family settled at or very near the Battle Ground in 1856. but afterwards removed lower down the River where he now resides -
  Their oldest daughter Mary Ellen was born almost upon the Battle Ground.  at least the nearest of any settler to it -  And the sentiments in the annexed printed Memoriam expressive of the grief of her friends upon her death in California in 1874 indicate a kindness of heart seldom surpassed by any one
  She died at the old Mission Dolores near San francisco January 1874

that Coose Bay was settled
Friday Aug 14 1874

   I set out on foot by a trail up the N. Fork passing by a few claims & then crossed the stream and turned off on a trail through heavy timbered bottoms to what is known as the Middle fork of the North fork of Coquille and at at[sic] 16 miles I struck the Coose Bay Wagon Road at Pierces - Here I met a wagon belonging to S. W. Crane of Roseburg & with them took passage home - Stopped for the night at Howes.

Saturday Aug 15 1874
Continued on and passed over the Summit of the Coast Range and put up for the night at Jenkins at the foot of the Mountains on the East side
Sunday Aug 16 1874
Reached Roseburg in PM

where she was attending school

  I remained at Hamblocks during the day & also for the night

Wednesday August 12 18874
With boat I again set out up River, again stopped at the Battle ground, and gave it the last look for the present.  and Continued up & stopped for the Day at Noah Tripps opposite the Mouth of [?Beaver?] slough an old Trapper friend of mine
Thursday Aug 13 1874
Went on up river by the afternoons tide and at sundown was at the junction of the North & south forks where I found a crew of men raising a bridge for a wagon Road across the said North fork at its mouth -

  This is the point where our party in 1851 took to canoes to go down the River - Then it was a howling wilderness full of hostile Indians . no settlements nearer than the Interior and the River to us and all the world then unknown - Now not a foot of land from the ocean . bordering upon the River but what is claimed  The Coquille Valley was settled in 1853 the same year

114
on the W.T or north side the River . a point recently attracting attention as the place fixed upon by the N.P.R.R. Co. for their intersection of the River, by the R.R. running South from Puget sound.   The Cars now run from Kalama to Tacoma on the sound the distance of 100 Miles    Course nearly north 

   Passing many Islands small towns & fisheries we reach Astoria at 2 30 P.M 110 m from Portland, Fare $1-00
  This is my first trip to "Astoria" - The name is historical - Settled by John Jacob Astor in 1810. on the South bank of Columbia about 10 miles from the bar upon narrow level trail of land . low and thickly timbered Mts immediately back of it.  population about 1000 -
   Fair view of the mouth of River & Ocean to the North westward   River about 10 miles wide . good harbor & excellent anchorage
   Sixty four years carries us back to a time when the great west was but little Known - Six years prior to that time the great Explorer Lewis & Clark crossed the continent & reached the Mouth of the Columbia where the [sic] passed the winter of 1805-6
   Thirteen years previous to that time Capt Gray of the American ship Columbia discovered the mouth of the River sailed into it took possession of it in the name of the U.S. & named it after his vessel - Astoria is the oldest place by many years in Oregon yet has been slow of growth - It is now improving with something of a degree of permanency -  The River is clear & sparkling bright . dotted with Islands covered with green foliage . the bordering mountains densely timbered with evergreens  fisheries abound at every available point on the River and it is astonishing what vast amounts of Salmon are put up for shipment each season - Narrow bottoms appear upon the River . generally occupied by settlers

Wednesday Sept 2d 1874

   Not well adapted to the more advanced order of civilization, that is gradually encroaching upon us western pioneers, I set out this day for a quite an extended trip into the Buffalo country on the plains of Northern Montana and British America
  Set out on the cars at 5 15 A.M for Portland the great commercial metropolis of Oregon. Day warm.  Breakfast at Oakland - dinner at Junction city.  crossed the Willamette River, passed through Albany, Salem, Oregon City & reached Portland at 4 PM Fare $12 25.  Meals 50 c each - Put up at Clarendon Hotel, Room 63 - Portland is considered the head of navigation on Willamette River.  is situated on the left or West Bank & contains a population of about 12000

Thursday Sept 3rd 1874
Remained in Portland, Day warm
Friday Sept 4t 1875
I concluded before going to the plains to visit Astoria and at 6 A.M went on board the Sternwheel Steamer Emma Haywood . and set out down stream . and at the same time the steamers Dixie Thompsen, Beaver & Welcome left the wharves for the lower ports and thus had the quite Novel sight to me of four River Steamers so near each other as to create a little uneasiness in the minds of some of the passengers but it soon subsided as our Steamer began to gradually leave the others behind

  At 12 miles enter the Columbia River and turn our head downstream to the westward touching at several unimportant points and at 38 miles stop at Kalama, the

Saturday Sept 5 1874

    At 5 30 A.M. went  on board the Dixie Thompson, a stern wheeler for Portland.  followed the sloughs and bayous along the banks and between the Islands & Main land touching at various mills and fisheries and arrived at Portland at 4 P.M.

Sunday Sept 6th 1874
Remained in Portland
Monday Sept 7 1874
Went on side wheeler [?"Oneanta"?]  enroute to Walla Walla.  set out at 5 AM. entered the Willamette & turned our prow up stream. touched at Vancouver . rounded Cape Horn perpendicular basaltic headlands on the north side and all the grand scenery & precipitous mountains & waterfalls of the Oregon side Castle Rock on the  W.T. side and at 1 PM was at lower Cascades 50 miles - River about ½ mile wide  Here we disembark on the W.T. side & enter the cars of the O.S.N.Co. and are whirled along over a good Rail Road 5 miles to the Upper Cascades where we again embark upon the River in the steamer Daisy Ainsworth and at 3 PM are at the Dalles.  Here we are at once rushed upon the Dalles & Celilo R.R. & proceed up River 15 miles to Cetilo [sic] where we arrive at 3 30 PM. and again embark on the Steamer "Yakima" : and set out up stream passing mouth of des Chutes River on the right encountered & passed the numerous rapids & rocks near the mouth of John Days River and at dark tied up to some small willows on North side
Tuesday Sept 8 1874
Morning pleasant. set out at daylight - warm occasionally a house and a few cattle & horses

the road where the stage was about to pass . with my rifle across my lap - when suddenly the Driver halted his team and in a sharp . quick and apparently excited voice ordered the passenger by his side to "Pass up the Express box quick" and to the passengers inside the coach to "Out with their gold dust and watches" for they were stopped by Road Agents - The Express box was thrown out . the inside passengers were squirming while I was as much surprised as any of them . but fearing that some of the inside passengers might while I was unguarded fire upon me. I threw my gun across my arm, only waiting an opportunity to explain that I was no road agent & had no notion of robbing the Stage  When suddenly all was quieted by a loud & hearty laugh from the driver which revealed to me the person of John Hulse an old stage man from Douglas Co. Ogn. with whom I had been intimately acquainted for years - He had recognized me at first sight & never does or says anything without a laugh & joke about it.  hence the seeming alarm

   I proceeded on and at 15 miles from Walla Walla crossed Touchet at a little town called Waitsburg   Ascended a long ravine & descended into another & stopped at a house for the night having travelled about 25 miles - The gentleman & lady of the house were absent.  the children (oldest girl 16) bid me very welcome and after several hours I was surprised to find that to be the residence of G. H.[? Bartges?] and [sic] old & highly esteemed friend of mine whom I had known for over 20 yrs and who I supposed lived in Sinn Co Ogn

Sat Sep 12 1874
Set out over hilly & treeless plain. upon a road with now & then a settler and at 15 miles cross Tucanon creek . small valley . few settlers

Sat Sep 12 1874
Set out over hilly & treeless plain. upon a road with now & then a settler and at 15 miles cross Tucanon creek . small valley . few settlers

117
but more likely by a white man
Monday Sept 21 1874
At 4 mile crossed the River for last time.  about 20 feet wide and commence the ascent of the Cordelaine Mt - about 3 miles to top. by a ZigZag course, reached by three angles in the road - at the summit you leave Idaho and enter Montana. and directly on the line you see one of Mullens land Marks. a hemlock tree, marked 246 miles from Walla Walla - Elevation 5000 feet above sea level - A gradual descent of a mile brings you on to the St Regis Borgia running East to the Missoula or Clarks Fork of the Columbia

  Follow down through narrow bottoms crossing the same 36 times & camp at an old cabin [?] called Packer Ranch or Crows nest - 24 miles

Tues Sept 22 1874
Crossed the St Regis 6 times in less than that number of miles then bore off to the left over a low range of hills and at about 20 miles reached the Missoula & crossed on a Ferry Boat to north side & proceeded up stream 4 miles &  camped 24 miles 
Wednesday Sept 23 1874
At 5 miles passed a house, at 18 another and at 22 miles another all farmers, camped on a small branch to the left in heavy pine timber - I am at this point about 306 miles from Walla Walla a little over half way to Ft Benton
Thursday Sept 24 1874
Saw several Flat head Indians today.  At 12 M turned up the mountain to the left. and move along about 6 miles on a narrow grade ½ or 1 mile above

Here are a few houses & store - Cross the Bridge & ascend low bluffs on North side. follow prarie for 5 miles crossing the line and entering upon the Panhandle of Idaho - One mile further through timber & then turn to the right & Camp at Spokane Falls:  deep gorge - fall about 12 ft in as many yds - Trout &c abundant
Friday Sept 18 1874
Follow up River. 8 miles to Cordelaine Lake  clear water  Several miles---in extent - Follow Lake 1 mile & turn to the left into the Mts & at 20 Miles Camp at Wolf Lodge a marshy prarie . streams running through it
Sat Sept 19 1874
Hilly for 12 miles thence gradually descend 6 miles down Rocky Canyon, thence over low hill  & descend to Marsh of several miles extent upon margin which is situated Cor.De-Laine Mission built by the Jesuit fathers in 1844 - Quite a little Community of Indians gathered around here giving the place a very pleasant appearance

  Passing Mission 1 mile Cross Cordelain River 50 yds wide Course South to Spokane or Cordelaine Lake - Follow up River about 8 miles & camp - Heavy timber nearly all day 

Suncay Sept 20 1874
This morning set out early . At 1 mile entered [?mud?] prarie . a willow Beaver dam marsh of 40 or 50 acres . thence up narrow bottoms of Cordelaine River crossing it 45 times & camp at Nigger prarie - So named from a Negro being murdered here - On the post at head of his grave, is the following - "Killed by an Indian

[postcard]
[printed caption]  Stanley del           Sarony Major & Knapp Lith 449 Broadway NY
[hand-written comment:]  Indian & half Breed camp  Going to Buffalo

the River then descent to the River again camped at a spring branch 23 miles
Friday Sept 25 1874
Passed two or three poor ranches and at 12 miles entered quite a settlement of French farmers & at 17 miles Came to French Town a little place of about a dozen houses situated upon a small tributary of Missoula - At this point leave timber & pass over a handsome rolling grassy plain for 10 miles & camp on a small stream
Saturday Sept 26 1874
Six miles, level, brought us to Missoula City with a population of about 600 beautifully situated on the level plain where the Hellgate emerges from the Mts - A beautiful grazing & Agricultural Country around it - Enter the HellGate Canyon just above town and at 5 m cross Big Blackfoot River about 50 yds wide and thence enter timber and at 12 miles further Camp at a little prarie on left of Road
Sunday Sept 27 1874
Passed three or 4 small farms & at noon crossed one Toll Bridge to opposite side River.  followed south bank for several miles . the road then turned up a small ravine to the right . and I soon camped at some good water a short distance above - Country open
Monday Sept 28 1874
Passed over a divide & descended gradually for 4 or 5 miles to Flint Creek 20 yds wide . an agricultural & mining creek . settled - Passing over some other low hills descend to the River again & follow up crossing a rapid Muddy Mining creek

[top of page obscured by folded piece of paper]
I proposed to [obscured by folded paper] and then turn my riding horse back for him which was done & he rode away - Not Knowing anything about the fellow I drew the cover off my rifle so if he proved to be a horse thief he would have no advantage - After crossing he thanked me kindly and as I rode off . he halted & said "See here Mr If I had been a horse thief I wouldnt have stole your horse after you [?skinned?] that Gun" - Camped about 4 miles above on a stream of clear water near farm house 22 miles

   Much teaming done upon this road from Helena to Missoula City, but little travel from there to Walla Walla

Tuesday Sept   29 1874
At short distance took left hand road over the hills to near the forks of Deer Lodge & Little Black Rivers, thence up Little Black Foot passing Meads station (Toll Gate) and soon after crossing the stream on a log bridge & camped about 6 miles above 21 miles - Killed an Indian today who I believed was .............[text covered by scrap of paper over right side of the next three lines] to steal my horses while I was away .......to kill a grouse on the side of the .................
Wednesday Sept 30 1874
At about 4 miles came upon 100 Lodges of Nez Perces going to Buffalo on Muscle shell River & on the Judith Basin on the East side of the Missouri River - These Indians go out every fall in large numbers . men women & children and often come in contact with the Sioux & Crows & frequently bloody Battles ensue - I travelled along about 8

miles with them when the [sic] camped at the foot of the Rocky Mts.  At this place I began the ascent which is gradual about 4 miles to an open grassy plain . with timbered surroundings, the summit of the Rocky Mts. the culminating point of North America . the dividing ridge between the Atlantic & Pacific, separating the waters of the famous Missouri on the East from the magnificent Columbia on the west  Descending by a good grade to the Eastward for about 3 mile & you leave timber & entering upon open & hilly land where I soon camp for the night
Thursday Oct 1  1874
Follow down a small Creek called 10 mile creek for about 9 or 10 miles passing several farms. where the country opens out into an extended level plain known as the Prickly Pear Vally of 20 or 30 miles or more in extent  Bearing to the right around the foot of the Mts you at once find yourself in Helena the Capital of the Territory . 5000 Inhabitants, mining & agricultural advantages &c.  Started out towards Ft Benton in a northerly course in the afternoon . crossed the vally and at about 12 miles entered the low foot hills & crossed over a low divide and camped   Saw two rabits [sic] which looked more like birds skimming through the air than like animals
Friday Oct  2d 1874
A rough & lively road today for about 12 miles to the West of "Little Prickly Pear Canyon" . which you follow down for about 10 miles crossing the stream 14 or 15 times - thence two or three miles up a little ravine and camp - 24 miles - Jumped up a splendid specimen of a Jack ass Rabbit today . Large - Long legged Ears white & as he sailed over the high bunch grass he appeared more like an Antelope or a white tailed

[ folded piece of paper covers first 6 or so lines of this page]
Open & hilly - no [paper covers the rest of the line]
noon descended the low Bluffs to the Dearborn River 60 yds wide . rapid, clear, S.E. to Missouri, cottonwood & willow bottoms - Over the same kind of broken hill land about 15 miles & camp on a muddy alkali swale
Sunday Oct 4 1874
Open & hilly for 12 miles to Sun River - 75 yds wide rich agricultural bottoms - settled - Ft Shaw in sight 3 miles above - Bluffs low & gradual - Follow down about 8 miles & then leave the River & travel more N.E. over a treeless space of 16 miles & camp at a Mud hole known as the [?Lake?] - Here I found a Teamster (Dud Rickard) encamped on his way to Ft Benton
Monday Oct 5 1874
We set out together and at 8 miles passed a Muddy Alkali spring called 28 mile spring. as it is that distance from Ft Benton - 20 miles further & we camped at another spring of similar character.
Tuesday Oct 6th 1874
Six miles over a smooth road came upon the left bank of the Missouri River . of about 100 yds wide running a northerly course through a gorge about 300 ft below the level of the surrounding country - Follow the Bluffs a short distance and descend to a level bottom & 1 mile further you are at Ft Benton . situated upon a sage flat on the left bank . with the bluffs surrounding it in a semicircular form . forming headlands a short distance above as well as below [? town? them?]   Its elevation is 2780 feet above sea level and by the

120
Helena Road 8 miles & camped at the spring where we camped on Oct 5
Monday Oct 12 1874

   Followed the Helena Road about 4 miles. thence bear off the right in a course about north west for about 14 over uneven grass land where we descend the bluffs to the Teton River & cross over to the opposite side & camped - A small growth of Cottonwood & willow along the River - Bottoms ½ mile wide - Heads in Rocky Mts & unites with the Marias River about 12 miles north of Ft Benton

Tuesday Oct 13 1874
Ascend the Bluffs & have nearly a level road for about 25 miles . camp in a Coulee at Ponderay springs . water in spots . Antelope numerous
Wednesday Oct 4 1874
North Westerly course 23 miles to Bluffs of Marias River . Descend about 2 miles to River which is about 76 yds wide . alkali water - Cottonwood & willows  Sol Abbott & Jim Scott have claims here and are building log houses and preparing to put a Ferry Boat in the River next spring - Squaw wives  Marias heads in Ry Mts - 150 miles long empties into the MO River 15 miles below Burton

  Charley Brown & squaw, and A.A. Tice with a team & freight for Wetzel & Co overtook us at this point & we travel together

Thursday oct 14 1875
Follow up the Marias 6 miles . thence ascend the Blufffs to the northward & camp about a mile from the River - Went to River for water - Buffalo chips for fire wood

the River is 3200 miles above St. Louis. It was located by the Fur Co about 40 yrs ago, named after Col T. H. Benton of Mo. contains a mixed population of about 500.  mainly supported by the fur trade  The first steamboats usualy [sic] reach this place in May, and continue to arrive and depart until about August when the water becomes too low for any further navigation until another season

   From Walla Walla to this point there are Prarie chickens. Pheasants, Ducks, grouse, Deer, Mountain sheep. Kiotas &c. yet game is not abundant anywhere on the route - I had a surplus all the way, but usually people get but little game on the route
  A few Antelope are found upon the plains as you near Ft Benton & Buffalo abound in great numbers during the winter season - Prarie Dogs. are common. & the prickly pear in many places cover the ground. [?Fool?] chickens and spruce partridges are found in Cordelain & Rocky Mts

Wednesday Oct 7 1874 At Benton
Thurs          Oct 8     "           DO
Frid             Oct 9    "           DO
Sunday Oct 11 1874
In Company with I. N. Clark an Employe of the firm of Wetzel & Co of Ft Benton. I set out northward with team loaded with dry goods for a trading post belonging to said firm & situated on the Old Mans River . a tributary of the South fork of the Sascatchuwan river in the British N.W. Territory at the foot of the Rocky Mts

  We left at 2 P.M and went back in the

[picture from a book]
[caption reads:]  MILK RIVER BEAR PAW'S MOUNTAIN IN DISTANCE
[identification under picture:]    Stanley del                      Sarony Major & Knapp liths 445 Broadway NY

Friday oct 16 1874
Six miles from camp & we find the road to enter the head of an alkali flat - level - which we follow 14 miles. thence bear off more to the left for about 10 miles & camped at the Foot of what is Known as the Rock Springs hill - alkali Water in Small Quantities - Antelope numerous
Saturday Oct 17 1874
Clark thought we would meet the Buffalo today So Vice & me rode ahead with horses - near the top of hill we found a good spring & abundance of water - From the highlands the road let of [sic] Northward and at about 6 m our attention was directed from the numerous bands of Antelope to 4 Buffalo Bulls about 3 miles off the first that had been seen - We approached within about 50 yds of them from a hill on the opposite side & succeeded in Killing one which was very poor of course -

  We waited for the teams to come up & soon after we saw a little band of 20 and at 2 PM we struck the southern margin of the big band scattered all over the vast plains for miles & miles to the E & W & farther than the eye could reach to the Northward  We soon reached our Camping ground in a deep Ravine called Red River . water in spots all tramped into mud by the Buffalo -

Sunday  Oct 18 1874
About ½ mile crossed the 49th parallel the boundary line between the US & British America passing over about 5 miles of hills to John Joes springs - so named from a Wolfer

121
[First few lines of text covered by a piece of paper;  text starts about line 3]
another tributary of the Mo. R. & here we camped for the night in the midst of an almost incredible mass of Buffalo - Milk R. is 20 yds wide & enters into the Mo. 300 miles below Ft Benton - buffalo within rifle shot all day
Monday Oct 19th 1874
Open country all the time. 18 miles we turn off to the left & travel about 3 miles & camp on some small springs Known as slippery springs had difficulty in driving the Buffalo away so as to get water for our own use - to day we cross the dividing ride [sic] between the Mo. on the south and the Sascatchewan on the North
Tuesday Oct 20 1874
Today we made a long drive through Buffalo all day at at [sic] 35 miles we reached the St Marys River and camped an hour after dark - 75 yds wide, runs to Billy river thence to the South Fork of Sascatchewan - At about sundown noticed a dead Indian laying on the left side of the Road
Wednesday Oct 21 1875
Cross the St Marys. this morning & ascend the bluffs to the level plain beyond and after 18 miles descend to Billy River & camp:  Here is a trading post called Ft Kipp and kept up by Power & Bro of Ft Benton - A few wolfers & traders of lesser note are camped here with their squaw wives - Among them John Joe - Charley Duvall - Rev Fitzpatrick - Wm Preston & perhaps others
Thursday October 22 1874
Gradually ascend to the level plains again & at 14 miles

descend the bluffs to the trading post of "Wetzel & Co" in charge of J.D. Weatherwax one of the firm

  This post is situated on Old Mans River . which empties into Billy River about 1 Mile below Ft Kipp - About 1 Mile above is a post Kept & run by one Canouse - Two miles above is the point recently selected by the British N.W. mounted Police for winter quarters and around there and above several other trading parties are located, trading with the Indians for Robes, and getting ready to trade with the Soldiers
  Heretofore Whisky has been quite an extensive article of trade . but the Troops are here to suppress the Liquor trade. hence the most of the traders . upon being advised that the Troops were coming . at once destroyed or Cached their liquor . so that but few on the north side of the line have any in their possession - The laws passed by the Dominion Govt in regard to the Whisky business in the Territory are very strict . and the penalties severe for having or selling or using liquor of any kind in the Country - There are no settlers in the country but the Hudson Bay Company . conspiring against the free American traders . with their vast amount of capital and influence have prevailed upon the Canadian parliament to pass a Code of laws . so severe & arbitrary in their operation as to enable them to furnish and actually drive from the Country any person of American proclivities whom they may desire & to enforce said laws . the Mounted Police force are clothed with both Civil & Military jurisdiction
  To day a party of men consisting of Harry Taylor John Samott - Sam Ferris & Bro - Bill Bond & Jo Butch . on their return from Pine Coulee 45 miles N.W. of here where they had been trading whisky were arrested by a Detachment of the Police.  their Whisky destroyed - Their Property confiscated & all marched to the Guardhouse except the younger Ferris who broke from the Guard

[paper obscures end of the first line of text]
& being mounted on a good horse made his[covered by paper]...... the U.S. line in safety - the other parties were afterwards tried by the Comissioned Officers & fined the full extent of the law - Jo Butch & Sam Ferris being; only employees thought to escape but were fined - imprisoned also - Weatherwax of the Wetzel firm some days later furnished the several parties money to pay their fines and all were released except Bill Bond who was Kept in prison a month or two on some trumped upon or imaginary charge. but finally made his escape from the Guard & froze to death on his way to American lines & was found dead by the [?Inds?] [?] in the winter
Friday Oct 23 1874
Saturday Oct 24 DO
Yesterday afternoon cold & at night commenced snowing . this morning Thermometer marked about 30[degrees] below Zero . & snow nearly a foot deep . Air glistening with frost - The Indians are stirring about dressed in their blankets & furs - the Buffalo are travelling [sic] southward at a rapid rate and cover the plains in every direction as far as the Eye can reach - Every body healthy and active - the pure and rarified air of the Mountains & plains enables the human system to resist and overcome disease  The Trappers, Traders & hunters, physically, are a noble set of men - they are children of the plains. at home any where - there is a Kind of a strange facination [sic] in their interesting, adventurous & dangerous life & they are continually dreaming of the good times coming when Beaver skins will command $5.00 per pound . as was the case when the oldest of their number were first initiated into their mysterious & romantic life and while they as a rule are addicted to habits of drinking & gambling . yet a more kind hearted set of fellows cannot

123
of the night & was up early.  loose frost an inch or more deep. Buffalo, horses & wolves were so completely frosted as to have the appearance of white bears - our hair & whiskers were at once whitened with frost & accumulating ice - during the night the snow drifted over us a foot deep and enabled us to Keep warm - We travelled about 20 miles in a straight course for Bow River leaving Willow Cr to the left & camped amidst the Buffalo on a bleak and dismal snowy plain
Wednesday oct 28 1874
As we go north the snow appears deeper & the weather colder - The wagon cutting through the snow creates a squeaking noise to be heard 10 miles . the atmosphere is bright & pure and an antelope may be distinguished with the naked eye 5 or 6 miles off - Clark & myself held a consultation together & fearing we might not be able to reach Bow River in a direct course we bore off to the left for Pine Coulee at the Eastern base of a long spur of the Rocky mountains where Taylor, Lamott and other outfit was captured, where we arrived at a little before dark - Here we had an old log cabin to sleep in and plenty of fire wood
Thursday Oct 29 1874
Say [sic] in camp today.  Killed a few Buffalo   The wind had blown the snow off the grass in a few places in the Coulee. but the Buffalo crowded in in such astonishing numbers that it was with difficulty that our horses could get any feed at all - a never freezing spring of water at the foot of the Bluff was disputed by the animals in the same manner

be found any where on the Globe - they are brave honorable . and hospitable to a fault - Educated in the School of danger they Know not the meaning of the word fear - They will readily sacrifice their property time & life itself in the defense of their friends when necessary . and as a class having been foremost in settling our new countries & borne the brunt of our Indian Wars are entitled to the favorable consideration of our Government
Sunday Oct 25 1874
Monday Oct 26   DO
Charley Brown & Vice having delivered their freight at Wetzels trading post returned to Ft Kipp on Billy river, and Weatherwax having sold some goods to one Dick Berry who is running a post on Bow River 100 miles north. Directed Clark to load his wagon & drive over to Bow river & deliver the goods as agreed upon  I concluded to go over to Bow River with him & we set out this morning, at an early hour . the eye dazzled by the glistening sun upon the wide expanse of snow - We went up the bottoms one mile & crossed Old Mans River at Canouses place . followed up Willow Creek a tributary from the opposite side for a bout [sic] 15 miles & camped at "Cut Bank"
Black mass of Buffalo in every direction and the snow beat down solid everywhere - the day was terribly frosty & night set in cold. Mercury marked 30 or 40 below - No fuel but Buffalo chips kicked out from under the snow
Tuesday October 27 1874
Last night was cold - Mercury frozen this morning   Buffalo crowding on every side - Big wolves all around us, and often gnawing our Buffalo Robes upon our beds . We slept but a small portion

124
Bill Hart Interpretter [sic] & Fred Delaney Cook   On the opposite side of High River nearby, one Ed Smith has a small Whisky trading establishment & has Rice & Shears as employes - High River is about 30 yds wide heads up in the Rocky Mts & runs north into Bow River - Bow River is about 200 yds wide heads in Rocky Mts runs N.E & forms the main South Fork of the Sascatchewan a small amount of timber along the banks of each stream - Here our trip terminates and our goods were unloaded & delivered to Berry as per orders

  A large number of Blackfeet Indians came in the P.M. to trade

Monday Nov 2d 1874

   The trading party of Indians aftr first selling their Robes & securing a goodly supply of blankets, beads & other trinkets, had a dance in the pure & in an unadulterated Indian style, dancing all over the house men on one side & squaws on opposite of room & dance to the music of a drum & accompanied by singing a regular Indian song common to nearly all tribes . while the dancing is done by the quick bending of the legs without raising feet from the floor

Tuesday Nov 3 1874
An old Black foot chief came in today from the north with a letter of recommend from on of the Hudson Bay men at Edmunston & wished me to add a litttle as a postcript to the same and in consideration therefor made me a present of a fine robe - I took his paper and wrote upon his paper as follows "The bearer of this is the meanest Indian in the Blackfoot nation.  He will lie, steal and commit murder at every opportunity - any person wishing to do his country a service will shoot him on sight"

Friday Oct 30 1874
We packed some wood into our wagon and set out . following up the Coulee over a low divide to a small branch called Little Moskito Cr a branch running N.E. to Little Bow River - Soon after crossed Mosquito Creek which unites with Little Mosquito Creek a few miles NE - and soon after Camped in the frozen snow plains
Saturday, Oct 31 1974
Colder - 12 miles crossed Little Bow River a tributary of Billy River and camped again in the snow - Today we got stuck in snow banks several times:  The snow drifting over the plains fills up the ravines & Coulees to one general level & a [sic] horses may be driven into them unawares - Buffalo were soon at short intervals to tumble into these places & disappear entirely from sight . and are often cast away & perish to make food for the wolves & Kiotas
Sunday Nov 1  1874
This morning early we came in sight of the groves of large Cottonwood timber on High River several miles to the left or west of us - These Groves are Conspicuous land marks in this vicinity & general camping grounds for the Indians furnish fuel for camp purposes - Indian name "Spit-See" - sometimes said name is applied to the River as well.  At 1 PM we reach the highlands at the junction of High River & Bow River & descend by a winding road down to High River & cross to the opposite side to Dick Berrys Fort at a point about ½ mile from Bow River

   Berry is doing a good trade.  Employes [sic] are

Wednesday Nov 4 1874
Loading our wagon with Robes we set out on our return - Ed Smith & his squaw accompanying us with his team also a small load of robes - We upset wagon on the hill near High River - Had a cold and snowy time in reloading the same - We Kept more to the right and camped on High River below Shitsee
Thursday Nov 5 1874
Clear glistening atmosphere - High Peaks of the Rocky Mts 30 m to the westward.  looming up grandly against the blue sky beyond - We reached Little Bow River & camped
Friday Nov 6 1874
Camped on [crossed out:  Bluffs of Pine Coulee]  Mosquito Creek
Saturday Nov 7 1874
Camped on Bluffs Pine Coulee
Sunday Nove 8 1874
Camp on Leaving of Willow Creek
Monday Nov 9 1874
Camped at cut Bank on Willow Creek
Tuesday Nov 10 1874
Arrived at Weatherwax's store in P.M. and I engaged winter quarters there when not away hunting or on other business

125
Frid Nov 20 1974
With the teamster Clark, I set out this morning after a load of Stone coal, at the Coal mine  1 mile below Whoop Up at the junction of Billy St Mary Rivers about 30 miles from here.  Camped at John Joes slept in house with Indians, dogs, squaws & pappoose all over the floor so numerous that it was impossible to step without interference with some one
Saturday Nov 21 1874
About 1 mile and we crossed Old Mans River & ascended the Bluffs on opposite side & passed over a level plain of snow 15 miles and descend by a long & winding route to the Coal mine on the left bank of Billy River - The coal vein appears to be about 3 feet thick & sticks out of the perpendicular bluffs a few feet above low water mark - Cold day
Sunday Nov 22d 1874
Last night was a terrific blustering night & continued all day, snow filled the air so that it was impracticable to face it - during the day we move out of our wagons to a small belt of timber about ¼ mile away - Buffalo & Antelope crowded into the timber all around us & a thousand Antelope I think could been killed in a short time if a hunter could have faced the storm
Monday Nov 23 1874
Not quite as blustering today - Clark [?dry part?] load coal
Tuesday Nov 24 1874
We completed our load today ready to start out tomorrow on our return - We have 3 yoke Oxen for a team & they are shivering of cold in the timber & it is surprising they do not freeze to death

126

Sunday Dec 6th 1874
Three Bulls, a celebrated Blackfoot chief having three squaws, discovered one of them in a position our white women often imitate . suddenly seized an axe & chopped her head off - If the same law governed the white race & was as promptly executed the prime cause of divorces now so popular all over the civilized world would at once be removed
Monday Dec 7 1874 - Tuesday Dec 8 1874  Wed Dec 9 DO
Thursday December 10 1874
Team today from Ft Benton Ed Tingle Driver been ever since October on the road - They report Joe [?Hye?] and a man by the name of Mitchell as being killed by the Piegans on the Marias River above where the Road crosses  - these men were whiskey traders & report has it that they became intoxicated & hence difficulty which resulted in their death
Friday Dec 11 1874 - Saturday Dec 12 1874
Sunday Dec 13 1874
A small War party of Bloods called upon us today on their way south to the Sioux Country after scalps & Horses - The Blackfeet, Bloods & Piegans are virtually one tribe and have one language in Common - Crowfoot is chief of all with numerous camp chiefs.  The Sioux are their hereditary enemies, they make annual raids into the Blackfoot Country around Ft Benton, on the Teton and Marias and as far

Wednesday Nov 25 1874
By working hard all day & making several trips to the top of the Hill with wagon. we managed to get our Coal & wagon to top ready for early start tomorrow
Thursday Nov 26 1874
Our Oxen are poor & nearly famished. we soon reached the wagon & set out but did not reach the crossing of Old Mans River until after dark & unyoking the Oxen, we tried to find the road to John Joes one mile away, but the snow had drifted so that we could not follow any trail or road.  hence decided to follow the river down on the ice 4 Mile to a Trading Post kept by Dutch [?Frd?] where we arrived in a short time covered with snow & frost & where we found cold but safe quarters for the night - Sam Sours cook soon had a warm supper for us
Friday Nov 27 1874
We returned to our wagon & yoked up our nearly famished Oxen & set out.  Colder than any day this season - We crossed OldMans River passed Fort Kipp & John Joes. ascended the hills to the bleak plains & at dark was about 5 miles from Our Head Quarters at Weatherwax store - We left wagon & took Oxen & set out & reached there at 9 P.M.
Saturday Nov 28 1874
Hunted up the Oxen & set out after the wagon &  returned to camp at 3 P.M.  Saw a couple of Indians on the road today. on foot. they changed their course to meet us &   came up on the run; they were in a high degree of perspiration from their violent exercise . while frost & icicles were hanging to their hair & dangling upon their face

Monday Dec 21 1874
Clark & Tingle came in with their coal today
Tuesday Dec 22 1874
Weatherwax sent Clark & Tingle & L. C. Baker with teams to Dick Berrys Fort on Bow River after robes purchased from Berry - Tom Haley a teamster brought a load of Coal in pursuance of contract
Wednesday Dec 23 1874
Thursday Dec 24 1874
Friday Dec 25 1874 Christmas
The mounted Police having completed their winter quarters. and desirous of securing the friendship of the Indians . called a grand council today to be held at Police Hd Qrs and promised a feast to all the Indians who would attend - Large numbers were present of Course & the Col Commanding (Col McCleod) Made them a rambling speech . exhorting them to be friends to the English instead of the Americans - Said the English had whipped the Americans into obedience & forced them to pay large sums of money for the country claimed by them south of the 49th parallel &c &c & while he was thus addressing the Indians the soldiers eat up the Grand feast . that had been provided . which done but little towards relieving them from their half famished condition

north as the Sascatchewan and generally get away with horses & often with scalps - While the Blackfeet are equally successful in their raids into the Sioux Country south of the Mo River - A war party is made up of from 2 to 50 young Indians on foot - encumbered with no baggage but moccasins . live upon game. sleep with scarcely any covering in some secluded spot by side of a Buffalo chip fire . are often gone weeks & sometimes months . while some parties never return . They depart with Indian ceremonies & if successful are recieved [sic] at home with a grand ovation

   The Indian names are curious in their way.  They apply the name of an Animal in as many different ways as the English language will admit of for instance Wild Bull - Mad Bull - Fighting Bull - Running Bull - Jumping Bull - Walking Bull - Flying Bull - Spike Bull - Mud Bull - Black Bull - Red Bull - White Bull - Spotted Bull - Sitting Bull - Three Bulls - Bulls Head - Bulls Leg - Bulls Rib &c &c and so on with nearly every other animal & bird

This would at first seem absurd to a white man, yet not so much so when you see the names applied by the white traders & hunters to their favorite squaws, whom they have taken as temporary wives while they remain in the Indian country, for instance Cayuse - Stomach - Broncho - Scappoose - Buzzard heart Gut eater &c &c
Monday Dec 14 1874  Tuesday Dec 15 1874   Wednesday Dec 16 1874
Thursday Dec 17 1874
Clark & Tingle with 2 Teams went after coal   David Aken an old trader came in from Ft Benton & H d McPherson an independent trader from the North came in from Big Bull Lake north of Bow river

128
having lost 5 head of horses strayed or stolen by the Inds had wasted considerable time in looking after them . but at last had rigged out two teams & left Tingle & one load at the Coulee until help could be sent to him

  Soon after dark the Troops came down . sized [sic] the robes & arrested Weatherwax for selling liquor to Inds at Bow R a place he never was at in his life - strong guard put over the robes & Fort - Every department of the house was searched for Dick Berry who was believed to be about the house concealed

Tuesday Feb 2 1875
Examination of Weatherwax at Fort today . many witnesses examined - The comdg Officer announced after evidence was all taken that he had not sufficient testimony to convict  [?Dept.?] or confiscate robes, but knew where he could get it & would get it - Sent Troops at once to Bow R. & arrested Ed Smith a trader near Berrys & brought him in, made a witness of him & pronounced Judgt that 700 robes should be confiscated . Weatherwax to be fine [sic] $500 - & imprisoned 6 months & carried the judgment into effect.  The Troops upon reaching Bow River found Dick Berry . Bill Hart . Price & Shears gone & Berrys Fort demolished
Wednesday Feb 3 1875
With 4 horses I started for Pine Coulee to aid Ed Tingle  It was a frightfully cold day . Cold & cutting west wind nearly direct in my face - distance 45 miles - The soldiers were on the road one day ahead - I passed them in Camp at 4 PM at the leaving of Willow Creek - I kept back 4 or 5 miles on the plain toward them - As they looked upon me very suspiciously I pushed on away into the night and reached the Pine Coulee Cabin at 10 P.M.  Ed heard me and met me ½ mile outside - I found him

Thursday Dec 31 1874
The last day of the year - Cold & severe  Mercury nearly frozen - Baxter & Wilson two of the British soldiers came down at dark on their way to Ft Kipp.  It was windy & blustery . snow filled the air so that it was impossible to see 100 yds - We tried to persuade them from going tonight and insisted upon their stopping till morning but they persisted in going - I followed them outside & told them they would get lost & freeze to death on the plain but it was no use . they set out & in a day or two both were found dead . perished rather than take the advice of those who knew more about travelling in the snow than they

The weather has been severely cold all through the month - Mercury frozen the most of the time
Teamsters I N. Clark & S. C. Baker & Squaw Came in from Bow River with two load of robes - Tingle the other teamster was in Camp at Pine Coulee . they

Butch & Tingle got in with the Robes and they were siezed [sic]  at once by the Troops who moved there part way to the Fort where they got stuck in a snow bank & fired their guns for assistance, this alarmed the Ft & every body turned out on the double quick fearing the Desperadoes as the Americans are termed had attacked their Detachment with a  view of recovering the Robes

   Robe case finished today Weatherwax Judgment confirmed - Ed Smith released probably on condition that he would convic [sic] Weatherwax . as he was a notorious whisky trader & traded straight along until the day of his arrest -
