Up to this time the Indians have been very uneasy in regard to the Weatherwax case & his imprisonment  They are all anxious to  have him released & dont understand why he is imprisoned & his property taken

   Mecasto a camp chief called today on his way to the Military head quarters . to interview the commander & buy him out of prison . They have an idea that Robes & horses will pay for any offense although often told otherwise

in good spirits having been 16  days on Buffalo straight -
Thursday Feb 4 1875
[many words in this paragraph underlined]  Ed determined this morning to make one More desperate effort to find the lost horses & set out toward Bow River & was gone all day & did not return until 9 PM: Of course he did not find the horses - During the day the soldiers came in & camped at the Cabin - and asked very many questions about Bow River . Dick Berry . Ed Tingle &c which knew but little about of course
Friday Feb 4 1875
Cold & blustering . the soldiers lay in camp today . but Ed & me harnessed up & set out at 11 A.M. homeward bound. horses poor & load heavy . we went down the Coulee about 6 miles & camped on the bluff on left side - poor grass - eaten close by Buffalo the snow being blowed away in places
Saturday Feb 6 1875
Drove all day hard but very slow and arrived at the leaving of Willow creek a little before night having Made about 7 miles - Dutch Fred and Spanish Joe came in soon after from  Whoop Up below Ft Kipp . on their wa to the Spritzer on High River & camped near us
Sunday Feb 7 1875
Gave Ed a good start this morning & both of us fearing the team would not stand it to get to the Fort I set out & travelled all day & arrived there at night
Monday Feb 8 1875
Weatherwax set Butch out with two fresh horses to meet Tingle - Weather moderating, snow wasting away

130
before life was fairly extinct
Tues 16 - Wed 17 - Thurs 18 - Frid 19 . Sat 20
Sunday March 21 moderate weather getting warmer . Snow gradually disappearing
Mond 22 - Tues 23 - Wed 24 - Thurs 25    Frid 26  Sat 27  Sund 28  Mond 29   Tues     30 - Wed 31
Thursday April 1 1875
The snow is off the main plains . lays in deep bands around hills & in Coulees - Ice all over the Country in ponds - a few Geese have been seen - running water in places in River - Old Thunder - a quiet & peaceable Indian camped about ¼ mile from us was killed last night by Canouses two [?] Indians who were tight & came down & fired a few random shots into the lodges on [sic] of them striking Thunder in head
Friday April 27 1875
Old Thunders Squaw & a few others were chanting the death song all night . around the house & Lodges and wandering over the praries - To day Mrs Thunder wanted a Butcher knife to perform the ceremony of cutting her legs but was refused her. however she went away & got one some where else & came in in the P.M. with a blanket on coming nearly to her Knees . while her legs below were cut & hacked in all manner of style & covered with blood . all the time chanting the death song as usual

   A few of us went out & gave the old Indian a respectable burial . leaving the old squaw wandering around . more like a hopelessly insane Indian than like one possessed of ordinary savage reason

Mecasto  returned in the evening . with a forlorn & sorrowful look
Mond Feb 22 1875 - Tues 23 - Wed 24 - Thurs 25
Friday Feb 26 1874 [sic]
Tonight the Indians were having a lively dance at the Trading Post and at 12 midnight . Dutch Fred & Jo Butch came in from High River - Fred had got into a quarrel with Spanish Joe & struck him on the head with a piece of wagon tire inflicting a wound from which he soon died & Butch was cursing Ed Smith who had testified before the Military Court different from what he did - and feeling guilty was hastening with Dutch Fred to cross the American lines - they rested a while and put out 
Sat Feb 27 - Sund 28 - Monday March 1 1875 Tues 2 - Wed 3 - Thurs 4 - Frid 5 - Sat 6
Sunday March 7 1875
Medicine dance today at Trading post - 15 Soldiers deserted last night & set out for Montana - At an Indian dance at a Lodge above . An Indian shot & Killed his squaw in consideration of some familiarity bestowed upon another buck -
Monday March 8 - Tues 9, Wed 10  Thurs 11 - Frid 12 - Sat 13 - Sunday 14
Monday March15 1875
An Indian run a poor old bull right up to the house & came near running him inside - Squaws 4 pappooses, climbed house corners . top of wagon & screams & yells were on order for a few moments until his Bullship was killed - He was dissected & his entrails divided up & parcelled out

131
& believing Brown & Butler to be below we camped  In the Afternoon a war party of 9 Blackfeet came along going north.  We ordered them away & as we each had a Henry Rifle they yielded a willing obedience & passed on
Tuesday April 13 1875
We stayed in camp until noon & then set out for High River in a course N.W. keeping on the left or south side of Little Bow over a comparative level plain - at 4 PM we crossed Mosquito Cr and camped soon after at a series of little Buttes with thousands of Buffalo all around us & hundreds upon hundreds of young Buffalo calves . tame & gentle scarcely able to run . all over the ground - These calves are invariably red & very much resemble a domestic calf
Wednesday April 14 1875
We reached High River in good time & camped . but found no sight of Butch & Brown , but discovered ½ Doz teams on High River a couple miles above us that had started two weeks ago to go out from the Police Head Quarters to haul in the robes of Campbell & Allen from Sheep Creek . the very place where we were going .  High River was up some and they had been laying here several days waiting to cross the River - We had supposed they had been to Campbells & gone back home again long before this.
Thursday April 15 1875
Tingle & I started early . crossed High River looking anxiously for Brown  & Butch . & finally saw them Coming up the River from a point below . having Crossed a short distance below us - Tingle took 4 of the poorest horses out of the teams & left

Sat 3 - Sund 4. Mond 5. Tues 6. Wed 7. Thurs 8. Frid 9
Saturday April 19 weather getting quite warm  Clark, Carlton & Tingle came in from High River today with two load of robes. having made a good trade. They managed to cross Old Mans River on the ice but it was rotten & dangerous - a Few geese are flying & & a few prarie dogs have been seen cleaning out their holes near the house . while other evidences of spring are at hand
Sunday April 11 1874
Jim Scott came in from Ft Benton representing that Wetzel & Co of Ft Benton had dispatched . Brown & Butch from that place to Sheep Creek north of High R to obtain & haul away from the trading post of Neil Campbell & Jack Allen two load of Robes. purchased from Dick Berry . at the same time the robes were purchased that the troops had confiscated.  These had been left at Campbells until they could be hauled away by a route over the untravelled plains to Ft Benton unknown to the Troops - We had ordered those teams to cross Billy river below Shoop Up and to go up Little Bow River & we would meet them some where near High River on a given day with more horses & a man to take charge &c

  We immediately got up 4 of our best horses and Ed Tingle & myself set out N.N.E for Little Bow River - We forded Old Mans River a short distance below. ascended the Bluffs & travelled about over the plains & camped 

Monday April 12 1875
Set out early, ground generally bare . but plenty of ice in ponds every where. Geese in great numbers all over the country & Buffalo plenty  struck the bluffs of Little Bow at about 11 AM

132
for an early start tomorrow . and taking my gun and going out along the River bank. I found by a water mark I made upon first crossing that the water was falling slowly . I concluded to make a desperate attempt to cross the River back again  We were soon harnessed up, had some difficulty in the River but was finally rewarded by seeing our two load of robes landed safe & dry on the opposite side . & driving a mile or two back from the River we camped for the night - Campbell & Allen & Obe & his teamsters all manifested much surprise at our precipitate action but were all satisfied by my telling them they were at work by the month while I had a contract for delivering our robes at the trading post & the quicker done the quicker paid

  Our real object of course was to gain all possible time over the Train of wagons under Obe, for their destination was the military fort & upon their arrival there . of Course it would be known that we had been after the confiscated robes of Wetzel & Co - By this seemingly very strange and uncalled for action we had gained at least two days time upon the other teams . for under ordinary circumstances it would take them a day to load & a day to cross . which might give us time to to [sic] get over the line before Obe would reach the Fort & the Troops overtake us

Saturday april 17 1875
We found Tongue River down & soon reached High River & crossed - Little Bow River heads in springs on the bottoms of High River near the Crossing & runs East & north Easterly about 100 miles & empties into Billy River about 20 miles below Whoop Up - To throw the Obe Teamsters off their guard as much as possible . we left the road at the crossing & hauled out to the left through the willows & Rosebrush & struck the prarie & struck out to the left or north side of Little Bow River instead of the

ours in  place of them & at once set out for Old Mans River . by a course to avoid the other teamsters back . & I took charge of the teams & set out for Sheep Creek . we soon came to Tongue River a small but deep & muddy tributary of High River  & was bothered some in crossing . but got across at last & reached Sheep Creek in the P.M. & camped  the weather had been warm for several days & the snow at Foot of Rocky Mts melting fast & did not appear as we could cross the Booming river for many days - I was worried, for the safety of our robes depended in getting them out of British America before the soldiers heard of us . because they were waiting  & watching for us to haul them in so they could sieze [sic] them as they had siezed the others of the same lot - In the afternoon late Campbells teams from High River Came in & camped with us - I assumed all the talking on our part as to our business & told them frankly that Weatherwax had concluded to haul the robes in anyhow & let them sieze them if they wished to . that he would bring the matter before the two Governments anyhow & he would let them all go together &c
Friday April 16th 1875
The River at same height . time was valuable to us . I set out to find a shallow ford succeeded in finding a place ½ mile or a mile above where we could cross possibly with empty wagons - We harnessed up & drove up to the new found ford

  Obe the boss of the other wagons rode up with us and after seeing us over . he hitched up his team & also drove over . Campbell & Allens Fort standing upon the other or north bank. we at once turned our teams out & selected a camp ground for the night
   In the P.M. we loaded up our two wagons preparatory

133
obtained about 1 doz goose eggs which were quite a treat to us - Several porcupines were seen sitting on the cottonwood trees.  the river did not fall today - and we were anxious for fear the military might strike our track somewhere & follow us up
Sunday April 25 1875
We moved our camp about 300 yds on to an Island where a large quantity of dry logs appeared . with a view of making rafts for crossing . A raft was made but it proved to be too small to take anything but one wagon without the load & Butch & I went over with it and throwed the wagon on the opposite  bank in pieces & returned . but in consequence of the swift Current we landed several hundred yds below & could not haul the raft up stream so turned it loose and selected timber for a better & larger one for tomorrow
Monday April 26 1875
We built a raft today large enough to carry our other wagon and all the Robes , loaded it and set out in the rapid Current . landed safely ½ mile below & loaded up our wagons again & drove down River a short distance further & camped
Tuesday April 27 1875
The Sweet Grass hills an isolated range of low Mts situated upon the national boundary about 20 miles East of the Whoop Up & Ft Benton Road . are splendid land marks to guide the traveller , and from this point bear abut S.S.E. by compass - Therefore to strike the road at the line our course would be about due south , we therefore made about 12 miles in that direction and Camped . at one of the numerous little ponds of water to be found at  any point on the plains at this season of the year

the south side where the main route lies - we drove 8 or 10 miles & camped

We made good time.  Buffalo numerous, crossed Little Bow to the South side and camped again at the Buttes mentioned April 13
Monday April 19 1875
Travelled about 5 miles and crossed Mosquito Cr  Continued on and camped on Bluffs Little Bow 2 miles below where we camped April 12th
Tues Apr 20 1875
Pretty straight course. E.S.E. 15 m. camp on high table land
Wed April 21 1875
More Easterly today. 12 miles drop Little Bow R to north side . and camp in hills 6 miles further

Bore off more to the right, passing below the mouth of Little Bow River & striking Billy River below & follow down 8 or 10 miles & camp
Friday Apr  23 1875
Billy River high . 300 yds wide . possibility of fording for many days - Drove down River about 5 miles & camped at a point where we propose to make rafts & cross unless the water subsides at once 
Saturday April 234 1875
Buffalo with young calves all around us.  Wild geese flying about . and building their nests.  some in trees & others on the ground - We climbed a few trees and

One of our horses so far gone he could not get up alone . we helped him up but he could not stand. he was shot & had to pull the load with 3 horses.  Camped in a Coulee

We reached the Marias River at 2 PM and crossed on Abbotts Ferry & camped at the foot hills

Wednesday April 28 1875
At 4 miles crossed a deep Coulee (E & W) and in another of similar character at about [?20 miles?]
Snow squally with cold north wind
Thursday April 29 1875
Snowed 3 inches last night . lay in Camp till 10 A.M. day cleared off warm & snow soon gone   Made about 12 miles . horses poor & weak
Friday April 30 1875
Snowed till noon . afternoon clear . Horses gave out at about 2 PM & was obliged to camp   Snow again off . was near Milk River & went out in advance of Camp so as to overlook the Bluffs.  Saw two teams on Milk River ridge going north towards Whoop up.  they drove down & camped on the River
Saturday May 1 1875
Cold blustering wind all night . We drove off S.W. about 3 miles & cached wagons & teams & sent Butch out on horseback to interview the teamsters seen last night, and ascertain if possible whether any soldiers were on the road at any point ahead of us. or whether they had seen any horsemens tracks - He soon returned & reported that the teams were those of Glenn and [?Harry?] Taylor of Whoop Up [?] been to Ft Benton . no soldiers nor no sign of any on the road - We were within one days drive of the line & concluded we would drive directly to the road and make the trip through without stopping which was done & we crossed over the 49th parallel at 4 P.M. safe with all our Robes &c

135

   This was the first instance in which the Col went in person. and the first instance in which he Ever sent out over 12 men in any one scout or chase

Friday May 14
Saturday May 15 1875 . Getting warm
The Indians from the Assinaboine Agency not long since stole a lot of horses from a few white tracers on the north side British line & drove them to the reservation. on Milk River about 175 miles below here - A party of a dozen whites went down a few days ago to obtain thembut the Agents & military refused to give them up . although they (the horses were there in the Corall
Sunday May 16 1875
A Squaw dance in town last night, quite an amusing affair . No women present but Squaws - And it was an interesting scene to see the fat & greasy old squaws trying to dance like white women, with Pullback dresses on
Tuesday May 18 - Wed 19 - Thurs  20
Frid May 21 - Steamer expected . bets on time pending
Sat May 22 - Sunday 23 - Mond 24
Tuesday May 25 1875
Montana passengers for the East are flocking in . to take passage down river on the first boats now overdue

  At night two or three men came a cross from a point 150 miles (via River) below & reported the Steamer Nellie Peck at that point this morning . All excitement

Wednesday May 26 1875
Saw the Smoke from "Nellie Peck" this evening some 15 miles down River - Great excitement prevails   Betting in every quarter as to the exact time when the Steamer will be at the wharf

that Jack Gorman & Frank Cassee were recently Killed a short distance below Benton by the Indians - I put up at Overland Hotel $15 per [?]
Mond 10 - Tues 11 - Wed May 12 1875
Thursday May 13 1875
A large band of Buffalo crossed the river about 1 mile above Ft Benton today , came down the bluffs in full view of town - A large number of Indians - half breeds & others went out to meet them & of course many were killed 
Today we heard from Whoop Up that Obes wagon train returned to the  Military Head Quarters & reported that we had been to Sheep Creek & had been gone several days with Wetzel & Cos Robes - the presumption of course could be nothing else . only that we had struck for Lower Billy River with a view of reaching the line by a route to entirely avoid the soldiers - Col McCloud the Comdg Officer with 20 men set out in pursuit at once . found our track & followed us a day in the direction of Billy river & believing we were so far in advance as to render it impossible to overtake us before we crossed over into Montana - he abandoned the pursuit within less than a half day of our camp while we were water bound on Billy River , and Constructing rafts to cross - We expected pursuit & attack & had agreed to drive our two wagons in position side by side - Brown & Butch to take position between them while I was to have position on one of the loads ; as soon as the Troops should appear in sight - and as they approached to be halted by me & if they persisted in making arrests I was to shoot down the Commanding Officer while Brown & Butch was to open at once from between the wagons.  We were all armed with Henry Rifles & by a sudden "onslaught" could (I believe) have got away with the 20 soldiers . armed with inferior weapons

Thursday May 27 1875
Everybody up early looking for the Steamer Indians half Breeds - Squaws & pappooses by the dozens were everywhere visible - Did not have to wait long . for before sunrise the Nellie Peck a fine river steamer slowly approached & made fast at the landing in front of town - 350 tons freight & 60 passengers - Left St. Louis on April 3 1875 =

  At 12 30 the new steamer Benton hove in sight & hauled in below the Peck . each Boat recd by salutes fired by the military

Friday May 28 1875
Steamers unloading & everybody busy - Scores of teams of Mules . horses and Oxen were hurrying to & from loading freight for the interior . for Helena & other points in the       Ty [Territory]  - At 12 25 the steamer "Carroll" arrived with a full freight & few passengers
Sat 29 = Sunday May 30 1875

   Went on board "Benton" for Bismarck /200 miles by River - $25.00 - neat little cabin State room E - Today a hale, hearty & robust teamster from the country partook pretty freely of Montana whisky & in two hours was a corpse

Mond May 31 - Tuesday June 1  1875
Wed June 2 1875
At daylight the Benton turned her head down stream . with about 30 passengers & a valuable Cargo of Buffa [sic]  Robes . Furs & peltries - The water being at a high stage, we made astonishing progress down stream . passing the Bad lands & reaching [?Carrol?] a small place 200 miles, at Sundown - Saw a large number of Mountain sheep on the sides of the hills today.  Antelope & deer

Steamers can run to Carroll nearly all summer . and frequently when dry are unable to go up as high as Ft Burton.  hence much freight is shipped from this point across the head of the Judith Basin to Helena & the interior of Montana
Thursday June 3 1875
Narrow bottoms. with Cottonwood & willow timber all along at 9 30 passed the mouth of the Muscleshell a considerable stream on the right - Met the steamer C W. Mead going to Ft Benton . at 10 stuck on Sand Bar - At 7 PM met Key West for Benton . tied up at dark on left Bank
Friday June 4th 1875
In 15 minutes we were at Ft Peck a handsome place on left at foot of bluffs . with River bottoms extending from there below - A vast amount of Indians at this point . Agency &c - 450 Miles from Benton

   At 20 miles from Peck pass mouth of Milk River on the north or left side - met Steamer "Fontenelle" going to Benton - at 4 P.M. stopped at the assinboine new reservation.  200 lodges . landed freight from Fort Peck - At least a thousand Indians . squaws & papooses lined the bank - As the boat moved away a Scouts wife a passenger on board was favorably impressed with the general appearance of a painted Indian & squaw standing a few yds the crowd . a [sic] very graciously waved her handkerchief at his lordship who, determined not to be outdone in politeness; pulled of [sic] his blanket and waved it over his head at the lady in return - The  joke on the woman was the Indian had on no other clothing whatever except his blanket 
   Tied up not far below . stuck fast in the quicksand

Saturday June 5 1875
An early start - Pass wood yard where man was shot a day or two ago - he fell across the woodpile . blood

137
here to Ft [?Gary?] (or Winnepeg city) 500 miles below on the Canadian side of the line & quite a brisk trade is being done in that direction - Fargo contains a population of 300.  Moorehead on opposite side of the River in Minnesota is about the same size

  Although the handsomest vally in North America . yet from its cold climate or some other cause, the country is but sparsely populated - Not ½ Doz settlers on the root [sic] from Fargo to Bismark . The land is owned to a great extent by speculators who will not improve it or let anyone else do so - Red River is about 100 yds wide muddy water & runs through a deep channel cut out of the level vally . banks of clay character - Land very rich & fertile . inclined to be wet in its general character - fine narrow belt of Oak. elm & other timber along margin River - otherwise  treeless country - Geese ducks & other water fowl in great abundance particularly in the spring of the year - while prarie chickens & other game abounds.  Fish in considerable quantities are caught in the River . catfish . Pike &c

Wednesday June 9 1875
Foggy morning . set out a 7. A. M. at about 30 miles you begin to enter scattering groves of timber - pass Detroit a Small town, & Detroit Lake . a beautiful sheet of water a mile or so in extent & soon enter a timber country - and at 75 miles face upon the waters running to the Mississippi, land become more of a swampy character . Tamarask, birch, cedar . elm . basswood, oak ash, Pine, Balm, spruce &c - Cross the Mississippi River & take dinner at Brainerd on opposite side in level timber land . 200 Inhabitants 138 miles from Red River - At about 3 P.M. we arrived at the [?N.?] Pacific & St Paul junction and in addition to the ½ Doz passengers, the St Paul passengers came

plainly visible from the Boat - At 4 P.M. crossed Old Ft Union an old fur companys post on left Bank and in a short time passed mouth of Yellow stone . apparently as large & as rapid as the missouri Coming in the south - One mile below is situated Fort Buford a handsome fort on left Bank, so artistically arranged as to appear like a neat little town - At this point or just above on Cross the line of Montana into Dakota
Sunday June 6 1875
At noon passed the "Katie P. Kounts" - At 1 PM passed the mouth of the Little Missouri coming in from the right - At 3 P.M. passed Berthold an old Fort and at dark Ft Stevenson & soon after stuck on Sandbar
Monday June 7th 1875
At 5 A.M. we landed at Bismark the western terminus of the N.P.R.R. situated 1 ½ miles to the eastward from the River.  Ft Abraham Lincoln on opposite side, below Small town. 600 Inhabitants - Mosquitoes frightfully bad - Grasshoppers going N.W. fill the air today - Minnesota-Dakota - Kansas & Nebrask [sic] & part of Montana suffering much from Grasshoppers -

  Met John Bowen, formerly a Lt in the Oregon Cavalry under me in the Snake Indian Country during the rebellion

Tuesday June 8 1875
Set out for Duluth Lake Superior . 500 miles $22.50 Rolling grassy plains - Dinner at Jamestown - situated near Ft Seward on "Jim River" - Arrived at Fargo on left Bank of Red River at 6 PM. Stop for night

   Red River vally large & extensive.  Chyenne [sic] a western tributary heads nearly over to Jamestown & runs through the vally, first S.E. then N.E Crossing the R.R. twice & emptying into Red River not far below - Steamers run from

138
at [?] out from the wharf at 7 A.M. into an East course down the Lake with numerous steamers & sail vessels in sight. for several hours the North shore of the Lake appeared visible but was gradually lost to sight . At 10 came in sight of the Apostle Islands a large cluster of small Islands belonging to Wisconsin and at 3 30 stop at Byfield on South shore nearly opposite the old [?Sapointe ?]  mission - Setting our passed to the left of Sapointe between the Madeline Island & those more westerly & steered for Ontonagan
Sunday June 13 1875

  Passed Ontonagan during night - Kewanaw point in sight this morning - Cold and a thin scum of new ice appears to be afloat upon the water , while the south shore appears white with ice in places  As we enter the Canal at the Portage we found the entrance so completely blocked with drift ice that it was only with difficulty that the boat could enter however got in about 9 AM & proceeded down to Portage Lake - Length Canal about 1 mile deepest cut about 25 feet - proceeded down the portage lake about 10 miles to Houghton City on the south side & Hancock City on north side - Each mining towns containing 12 or1500 population & a vast amount of Copper is shipped therefrom   The surroundings are of a hilly character of timbered with a variety of timber very much of which is evergreens - Sail boats & small steamers are numerous . running in every direction indicating a brisk business &[? thrifty?]  places 
  Business settled at these two points the Steamer instead of passing on down the Lake returned by the Canal & pushed through the ice out into Lake Superior again and [?] on down Keweenaw point - And at 2 P.M. halted at

on board filling our cars to their utmost capacity, Leaving the Junction we at once cross the St Louis River & follow it down on north side in full view of its numerous Dalles & cascades . forming the most beautiful scenery in the Lake Superior country.  passing along for 8 or 9 miles almost upon the track of the old Portage or Canoe route [?after?] Indians & fur traders of earlier days and over which I passed in 1850 - Reached Duluth at 6 30 P.M. a fine place of about 2500 Inhabitants, situated on the both side [sic] of the mouth of the River on heavy timbered lands . partially cleared and arising gradually as it extends back from the River or Lake .  This is the main shipping point for the surplus farm produce of at last [sic] the North ½ of Minnesota . which which [sic] finds its outlet via the great Lakes Eastward -
Thursday June 10 1875
Stayed in Duluth.  bout [sic] ticket for Sault-Ste-Marie - 500 miles $18.00  How different things appear to me than they did in 1850 when with a few Indians & half breeds I was encamped at this place with not a white settler nearer than the Copper mines at Ontonagan 200 miles East of here - Now the vast amount of rail roading . shipping manufacturing business &c contrasts strangely with the Indian canoe song of that earlier day - Superior City on opposite side about 4 miles away seems to be of some importance but like Duluth appears to be Dead at present in consequence of the suspension of all further business in Rail Road building
Friday June 11 1875
Saturday June 12 1875
Went on board the Steamer Kewenaw at 6 30

Eagle River, a small copper town, a mere shipping point - Soon set out and at sundown Entered Eagle Harbor . pretty harbor and a very pretty small town . not improved much since 1849 & 1850
Monday June 14 1875
We sailed out of Eagle Harbor sometime during the night and at sunrise was off Kewanaw point with the little Manitou Island a little to our left and at 8 AM broke down some part of the Engine machinery and at 11 had it so repaired that we set out and at 12 30 had the little rocky granite Island & Sight House a mile or two to our right & soon after the machinery again gave way leaving the steamer lying like a log on the smooth surface of the Lake - A Yawl was immediately dispatched for Marquette about 15 miles . for a Tug boat but the propellor "Annie S. Craig" coming along was signalled & came to our aid & took the Keewinaw in tow & reached Marquette nearly as soon as the Yawl - Had it been stormy weather there probably could been no power to have prevented the Keewenaw from being blown ashore & wrecked before the Craig came to her assistance

   Marquette is the great Iron point of Lake Superior, has 6000 population. No agriculttural [sic] resources  Rail Roads running back to the mines 15 or 20 miles back in the Mountainous regions south of Lake  the Rail Roads are built out over the Lake & ships are loaded with oar [sic] direct from the Cars overhead by opening a trap door from underneath the Car & precipitating a Car load at once into the hold of a vessel by means of a shute &c
   Thousands of Cords of pig Iron is seen everywhere & everything appears to all life bustle & activity  Fine buildings -Timber plenty . harbor good &c

139
[top line partially obscured by folded paper]
At 9 PM the pasengers from [covered up but probably: Keewenaw were] transferred to the "Annie S. Craig" & soon set out down the Lake
Tuesday June 15 1876
Early in the forenoon the Canada shore became visible & at 10 30 we rounded White Fish point & turned more southerly passing Parisien Island (to our left ) and at 3 PM. entered the Sault river & at once into the Canal which is passed by 3 Locks & I landed at lower dock
The Rapids at this place . or falls as they are generally called , have been a great draw back to the Lake Superior Country . but Government aid in 1853 caused the Canal to be opened which done much to open up & develop the rich mineral regions of Lake Superior - The Rapids are about ½ mile long. falls about 20 feet  Mackinaw boats & canoes often rundown over them & much fishing is done on these rapids principly by Indians of course
Wednesday June 16 1875
Today I went on board the "Eva English" for Mackinaw - The River below about 1 mile wide Banks thickly timbered - Mosquitoes plenty  Was at Point Detour . the entrance into Lake Huron at 6 P.M. here we turn more westerly and landed at Mackinaw at 11 30 P.M - 100 miles $4.00 -
Thursday June 17 1875
Visited Arch Rock. sugar loaf & other natural curiosities & the Island generally - Mackinaw Is [Island] is a full chapter of thrilling historical incidents.  Its position commands the straits its fort overlooks the City & Surrounding waters

people were present to witness it & quite a number of persons had taken position on the roof of a building near by which gave way & several were quite severely hurt and in the evening a boy boy [sic] who was badly hurt was reported dead

   A day or two previous a sad R.R. accident happened about 1 mile west of Holly on the D&M.R.R. - Two trains in attempting to pass each other on the same track collided with a terrible crash. twenty or 30 Emigrants in one Car were severely hurt but no one was killed

Sunday July   4 1875
Monday July 5 1875
Left Holly at 12 noon for Grand Rapids by the Detroit & Milwaukee Rail Road - when within 6 m of Grand Rapids, saw Prof Donaldson with 5 or 6 newspaper reporters descending in Barnams big Baloon [?very?] the track ahead - They being in danger of dropping on the Cars or track . threw out a rope & Made fast to the top of an oak and hung there while the train paper, amid the swinging of hats & waving of Hakfs - Soon after at a station it was announced that Barnams Grand Hippodrome was exhibiting at the Rapids and the Balloon was a part of the attractions - Ten days later Doneldson ascended from Chicago with the intrepid reporter Grimwood with him & were overtaken by a storm & lost in Lake Michigan - In the Evening at Grand Rapids I visited the grand show & witnessed the largest concourse of people I ever saw  15000 - After the performance one of the showmen was Killed by some portion of the timber falling upon him - Put up at Sweets Hotel and ws carried up a shaft by machinery to the upper level of the Hotel where I was assigned to comfortable quarters for the night

a great summer resort  [obscured insert: ?population 2000?]  9 miles in circumference & the prettyest [sic] place on the Lakes - The Island by late act of Congress has been made a National Park
Frid June 18 1875
Saturday June 19 1875
Went on board of Steamer "Music" at 4.20 P.M. and set  out westward through the Straits passing BoisBlanc and St Helena Island and entering Lake Michigan . rounding Point    [?Mare-le-chance?] and at sundown entered Little Traverse Bay, and soon lay at wharf at "Petosky" on the opposite side of Bay from Little Traverse city - Petosky named from Indian chief of that name is a new Rail Road Town & at present the northern terminus of the Grand Rapids & Indiana R.R. contains 500 population built in the [?woods?] has good harbor . but few other advantages
Sunday June 20 1875 
At 8 P.M. went on cars of Grand Rapids & Indiana R.R. and set out into a dense forest with fires burning in nearly every direction
Monday June 21 1875
At 3 AM was at Reed City the Junction of the Grand River & Indiana Road & the Flint & Pere Marquette Road  Set out on the latter at 8 A.M. and reached the Saginaws at at[sic] 11 and Grand Blanc my former home at 4 P.M
Tues 22 - Wed 23 - Thurs 24 - Frid 25  Sat 26 - Sund 27 - Mond 28 - Tues 29 - Wed 30 - Thurs July 1 - Frid July 2  Saturday July 3 went to Flint on train . thence to Holly and saw the celebrated Paul Boynton submarine armor . and also a man cross small Lake dressed in same . he resembled a large Mud Turtle more than a man . wallowing through the water - A large concourse of

Tuesday August 10 1875

   Tire [sic] and heartily sick of the country and everything in it   I left Grand Blanc on my return to the West - Went on the Flint & Pere Marquette R.R at 10 AM and at sundown was at Ludington in the East shore of Lake Michigan the western terminus of said road - Here the passengers go on bord [sic] the Steamer John Sherman & sail across the Lake during the night time for Cheboygan -

August 11 1875
At sunrise landed at Cheboygan . a city upon a hill - stayed until 3 PM & went on cars for Green Bay - Passed over handsome Country & was soon at south end of Lake Winnabago in Wenibago [sic] County . one of the most patriotic Counties in Wis. that has through its agricultural organizations . extended an invitation to Jeff Davis the ex rebel president . to deliver an Agricultural address in said Co. which invitation has been accepted by his Ex ship  Reached Green Bay City at 9 PM & stopped for night
August 12

      At 9 AM was on the cars again . and reached Escanaba at the mouth of Little Bay De Noguet  at 1 PM . thence across the densely timbered upper peninsula by rail and at dark was at Negaunee a brisk little town of 2000 Inhabitants in the heart of the Iron mining regions - Here we change cars and in an hour and a half was at Marquette on Lake Superior. the great Iron shipping point of the Upper peninsula. where we get very expensive Board & not much to eat

Aug 13  stayed at Marquette

Tues July 6. Grandville
Wed July 7 - Thurs July 8
Friday July 9th 1875
Returned to Grand Blanc by the D. & M.R.R  130 miles
Saturday July 10 - Sunday 11  
Monday July 12 1875
Visited Saginaw & saw the Orangeman on parade
Tues 12 - Wed 14 - Thurs 15 . Frid 16. ret to Grand Blanc  Sat 17 . Sund 18  Mond 19
Tuesday July 20 1875
In Company with Martin Tyler merchant of Detroit & Orin Stone and Damon Stewart Merchants of Flint I went to Saginaw & thence by Rail Road North to Hq Roscommon station, where we disembarked from cars & hired a team & drove to Higgins Lake about 6 miles. a handsome lake of transparent water with fine sand beach and beautiful surroundings of Pines & other evergreens fine fishing in the Lake
Wed July 21 - Thurs 22 - Frid 23  Sat 24

there & they gradually drifted down . landing up [?] bank and galloping off a short distance to look [?] back upon us in much wonder and astonishment - Reached Carroll on Sunday Sept 5 [?]

  About 4 miles below Carroll discovered [?a?] skiff half full of water, fast on a snag . it contained gun, blankets & camp outfit [?generally?] the oars lying in the Rowlocks, and attracted some attention . upon reporting the same at Carroll It was found that it belonged to a man who had started to go down River a few days ago & had probably been drowned

Monday Sept 6 1875
In company with Charley Thompson purchased a pack horse & set out for Cow Island about 40 miles above, where a load [crossed out: or] two of freight recently been landed by the steamers Benton and Mead - and at which point we believed we would find teams [crossed out: to] which we could accompany to Ft Benton where we both desired to go

  Two of the "Glendening Bros" were going up the River 10 miles to a hay ranch on the south side of the [?River?] & we went up in Company . by a poor trail along [?] near the River bank the worst of the way . We found two men encamped there upon a timbered bottom adjoining some meadow lands - Here we had dinner & there crossed to the north side of the river & swam our horse & followed up stream about 10 miles & camped - Saw a few [?deer?] but game did not appear to be very plentiful

This section of country is always infested by hostile Indians hence we travel with extra caution, always on our guard and at no time out of reach of our rifles - We did not make camp until about 2 hours after dark

3
144
had encamped there the night before and were now packing up and nearly ready to start

   Our appearance on the side of the bluffs as we wound down on to the bottoms attracted their attention.  Guns were brought into requisition but the train master with his glass soon made us out to be white men & after the first curiousity {sic] of meeting had subsided . they returned to their work and very soon rolled out ½ mile up the River thence turn to the right more northerly up Cow Island Creek where we soon met 8- Eight mule teams belonging to Capt Smith a noted freighter upon the upper Missouri 
   We found two or three acquaintances with this outfit & returned and camped with them at the Cow Island landing

Thursday, Sept 9 18875
The teams being loaded set out this morning - A portion of freight still remains & hired men from Benton are here guarding it - Thompson with horse accompanied that wagons . while I ascended the high hills & travelled about 5 miles parallel with the road crossing several Canyons and passing around the head of others when I saw two sheep (big horn) consisting of an old Ewe & half grown lamb.  I fired at the old one & hit her about the middle of the body   They run down the steep & precipitous spurs of the Mountains to the vally of Cow Island Creek & on their course fell in with half dozen others & all making quite a little band could be seen sailing over the alkali bottoms & flats along the Creek

after contemplating the sad scene around us & picturing in our imaginations the last and most desperate struggles of these hardy pioneers, which class of men I have nearly all My life been associated with - and their gloomy and sad fate we move on up stream about five miles and camped a little after dark tired and weary . not knowing how much farther we may have to go before we reach the freight for Ft Benton which we know to be landed at Cow Island -
Wednesday Sept 8 1875
An early start again this morning and being out of meat I set out a head [sic]  to look for game as well as for Indian "sign" and soon Killed a fat deer and Thompson coming up with the horse we packed a hind quarter on & continued along following a poor Indian trail the most of the time along bottoms or shaving the points & cutting off bends

  We soon reached a high perpendicular head land on the right with bare room to pass on a narrow trail when suddenly we were startled by the sound of voices and a yell not far above us - The horse was halted in care of Thompson and with my gun I ran on a head [sic] and carefully looked around the turning point & what we had feared was Indians appeared to be teams & wagons and as many "trails" arranged along side the goods . nicely piled up at the lower Cow Island landing . and there were the teams from Ft Benton after the [?same?]  -  We moved up & found the teamsters

4 145
near where the sheep were killed the mountain tops are litterly [sic] covered with petrified oyster shells indicating a different condition of country at one time than now - The hills are barren . no vegetation - soil light - alkali   occasionally a tree around the canyons &c
Frid Sept  10 1875
Our course was northerly up the little alkali vally, miserable poor water in patches . only made about 5 miles & camped - A Deer and a Buffalo was killed by me today . Only a few Buffalo were seen . the scattered remnants of the larger bands that moved north in early part of summer .
Saturday Sept 11 1875
We only made about five miles further today and camped at a small patch of alkali water at a point where the road leaves Cow Island creek and bears off to the left to the plains . more to the westward - Roads sandy & hence slow progress
Sunday Sept 12 1875
It was about 3 miles to the top of the hills & the teamsters being obliged to drop their "Trail wagons" causing them to double trip it, consumed the most of the day in getting the wagons up & we camped at the top
Monday Sept 13 1875
[?Roads?] had made about 4 miles along the hills parallel with the creek & camped, and drove the Animals down into the creek bottom for water & also packed water in a couple of Kegs back to camp for use

crossing the wagon road & heading directly for an immense canyon on the opposite side - I clambered down the steep Mts. crossed the little vally to the road & say [sic] that our Mule wagons had not yet passed along . therefore went over to the mouth of the Canyon where the sheep had disappeared . saw plenty of blood from the wounded one - Ascended the steep & almost perpendicular spur on the left for at least 3000 ft to near the summit. thence following the ridge back soon discovered that the Canyon although deep & dark was not to exceed two miles in length & if proper caution was used the wounded sheep at least could be had - I soon discovered the little band on the opposite side of the canyon too far however for a shot.  they were about half way from the bottom to the top of the high bluffs & directly at the foot of a perpendicular cliff of about 30 ft high - I passed around the head of the canyon & in returning to where the sheep were seen . discovered another little band lying down and a large Buck of 300 pounds weight was killed - Proceeding to where the others had been seen . the wounded sheep was killed but the others scampered away around the side of the almost perpendicular cliffs apparently with more speed than an Antelope on the level plain - In a few moments the lamb belonging [?] dead Ewe returned to look for its mother and as cruel as it may seem to some people was Shot also. and all three of these rolled down the high Mts to the road just as the teamsters came along - a little alkali water was found in places & here we camped

5 146
follow up the narrow sage brush bottoms of the latter stream . crossing it nearly a dozen times & finally camping on the left side or south side
Sunday Sept 19 1875
Reached Ft Benton at about 2 PM. all in good condition - Steamboats often land freight at Cow Island when the water is too low for them to reach Fort Benton - When this is done the Fort Benton Merchants are obliged to send out their teams & haul the freight the balance of the way by the route travelled by us  Large trains are generally engaged so as to interpose a formidable resistance to the numerous bands of marauding Indians . found every Autumn in and about the "Bears Paw" Mts where they resort for hunting purposes, as Game such as Deer . Bear . Elk, Mt Sheep Antelope, Buffalo &c are found in great abundance in and around those Mts. and particularly in the fall of the year.  Any straggling party of Indians or whites who happen to be attracted thither . have to be very cautious & guarded in every particular . or else they are likely to lose their scalp lock which [?....able?] appendage will be carried away as a trophy attached to the belt of the wiley [sic] "Sioux" at present the greatest terror of the Bears Paw
Monday 20
Tuesday Sept 21 1875
Crossed the Missouri at this place & with a riding horse & pack Animal and a pretty good outfit generally set out up the river by keeping its general course

Tuesday Sept 14 1875

  Our course is North westerly over a gently rolling grassy plain. destitute of timber , directly towards the "Bears Paw" Mts, an isolated range of about 30 miles in extent E &  W. apparently thrown by some convulsion of nature . from the surface of the comparatively level plain around there - We made about 12 miles & camped - a few antelope were seen to day . but the Buffalo appear to have left these plains a few weeks ago & gone north

Wed Sept 15 1875
Ground slightly hilly today, made good drive camped on small tributary of the Mt. Killed Antelope & saw many more
Thurs Sept 16 1875
Passed a fine spring of good water at the point of an eastern spur of the Bears Paw, passing which a few miles we camped without water only such as we hauled in the wagons.  Antelope abundant, several Killed
Friday Sept 17 1875
For 20 miles we have been travelling [sic] along parallel to the Bears paw Range and from 5 to 10 miles therefrom, & today being nearly south of the western part of said Range , we turn more southerly & camp at an Alkali water hole for the night.  several Antelope killed
Saturday Sept 18 1875
We reached the Marias River today & drove the teams across about ½ mile below the Mouth of the Teton - A white man with squaw wife living here - after reaching the south bank we ascend the river to the Teton

& travelling [sic] over the level table lands a few [?miles?] back therefrom, my course was about S.SW [?] the Deep Gorge of the Mo R. to the right and "Highwood" Mts a few miles to the left and at [?] miles I descended to the little valley of Highwood [?] a 20 foot stream of quite pure water running through a handsome little vally [sic] from the [?] Mts to the Missouri River - Two or three [?settlements?] on  the stream below, and being a fertile [?valley?] with rich surroundings of splendid pasture land will evidently be soon settled up - Saw [?several?] bands of Antelope to day & a few deer along the brush upon the creek
Wed Sept 22 1875

 A course from here, about W.S.W over the same kind of plains  10 miles brought us to the deep [?] of Belt creek at 1 P.M. a stream about the [?] of Highwood running from Belt  Mts . south of the Highwood into the Mo - In the afternoon I struck down on South side for the Great [?falls?] of the Missouri which were soon reached and partialy [sic] examined today - It is said the River falls about 200 ft in about 10 miles, the lower perpendicular being at 75 ft - the next 12. the 3d about 30 and the upper fall about 25 ft  Camped on the River at the mouth of a small Coulee, saw [?many?] Antelope today & as they are beginning to band together . are easily attracted by a flag or HandKerchief being raised on the end of a gun or better to be fastened to a ramrod and stuck in the ground at some point where the hunter can conceal himself behind a rock, knoll or bunch of Rye grass - Attracted towards it [?the?] Animals approach within a few yds and are killed easily

& returned immediately to my camp . found my own horses undisturbed, saddled and packed up. and set out at once up river not knowing whether there were any others in the vicinity or not - I believe the Indian was a Blood & on a marauding expedition & happened to discover the Bull, probably the only one in many miles of here and had given chase with the result as related above - I passed up the river by the upper falls, cautious & guarded in every step. and halted in the middle P.M in a secluded spot and turned my horses out to graze, while I took a position on a high elevation near by . where by the aid of a glass I could scan the country for many miles in every direction - I saw a large number of Antelope, but no Indians or Buffalo - after dark I again hitched up & rode about 10 miles over highlands & across gorge of "Deep Creek" a stream 40 ft wide from Belt Mts to the Mo. River . here I camped at 12 midnight
Friday Sept 24 1875
Believing that a S.W. course would take me to the Mo. River not far from the position of a recently established ferry above the mouth of [?Sun?] River I [?layd?] my course & struck the River at noon . & found a cabin occupied by a white man & stopped for dinner - I related the story of the Indian & Buffalo & he informed me that there are a few Buffalo Bulls around & about the falls nearly every summer . that this Indian was a Sioux & probably belonged far up the River that he had passed down a day or two ago - knew no harm in the "poor Indian" but was well pleased to think I had killed him

Camped on Tucanon [crossed out: at] little before night one of the settlers [crossed out: cross] came into camp & requested me to go down 1/2 mile & shoot a  wild Boar, that had been several years running in the bottoms & had become very vicious . so much so that it was considered dangerous for footmen to go about near where he stayed - the animal was pointed out to me 1/2 mile off running with a few tame hogs in a stubble field - I was cautioned to strictly on my guard &c - I crawled a long distance on my hands & knees & approached behind a bunch of Rye Grass & fired . the ball going into one eye & passing out at the opposite ear - The hog fell without a squeal. [newspaper clipping]

  Our highly esteemed friend L.L. Williams, again made his appearance among us Tuesday evening last.  He is looking hale and hearty, in fact much better than when he left us something over a year ago.  He must have been well treated by the people of "Whoop up" B.C,.  We have not had a talk with Mr. Williams yet, and cannot tell where he has been, or what he has seen.
